headline: Excellent Workplace, Cutting-Edge Tech
pros:
The software org that I was in had excellent culture and allowed for healthy work-life balance. The leaders allowed us the freedom to take care of the work as we best see fit. Other employees take time to help you. Everyone was great to work with, and I genuinely enjoyed coming to work on Monday. 

Work on cutting-edge technology reaching many millions of people.

Flexible PTO is better than many other large tech companies and allows for more flexibility and peace of mind. On-campus benefits such as gym, cafeterias and coffee shops are great. 401 (k) match, ESPP program and donation matching are good. Vesting schedule is 3 years instead of the usual 4. San Diego is a great place to be and vastly better quality of life than the Bay Area and LA.

Once pandemic remote work ends in April, they plan to allow a hybrid work approach where you only need to come in two days per week. Depending on your team, this might be even more flexible. This is a much better policy than Apple's.

The business outlook for Qualcomm is bright. They are the inventors of 5G and are expanding into strong new markets such as auto. The acquisition of Nuvia will lead to chips that beat Intel and AMD.

Work with very smart and diverse people. There is so much going on at Qualcomm that you can always find a different team doing something that interests you.

The CEO is an industry genius and gives candid Q&As during quarterly all hands. 

Dev environments are usually Unix-based.
cons:
As with any large company, culture can vary between groups and teams. You can't generalize for a company of this size. 

Being a chip company means that most teams will not formally allow fully remote work once the pandemic ends. They expect you to report to an office because your work will likely involve interfacing with hardware of some kind.

A minority of especially entitled employees suffer from "we aren't Google" syndrome and choose to complain and moan that the (already great) benefits and compensation aren't as stratospherically high as one or two other tech companies. Ironically, expect to hear these same employees also complain about "morale."

Employees outside of the San Diego HQ miss out on some of the benefits that come with being at a main campus.

The annual review process is time consuming and basically shuts down the company for one week.

headline: FOR RF360 SINGAPORE! Beware: Don't trust the "Qualcomm" branding! Low loading & hiring freeze!
pros:
Very nice, friendly and supportive colleagues. This is the only support system that can help you go through each day.
Retirement place if you want to be a yes-man or if you join.
RSU (Entrance stock grant), ESPP (up to 15% of base pay).
cons:
Too many negative experiences here, hence 1-star review. 
High turnover rate in Operation (Front end).
Low loading from December 2021 (Context: Semicon is booming due to chip shortage, yet this company loading drops significantly!).
Hiring freeze since Jan 2022, OT is also highly controlled since then.
Under Qualcomm branding, but culture and system are still RF360. Systems are messy, little to none automation (OI & IT team are stuck in another dimension?).
Manual fab with manual work!
A few sites in Singapore are getting shut down.
Very minimal increment, below industry's benchmark. Only received $10 increment in 2020.
Firefighting everyday doing line sustaining with not much value-added projects.
Very slow career progression, management favours old birds who are "loyal".

headline: Lots of boomers who won’t retire
pros:
-Less stressful than other tech companies to work at 
-People are usually pretty nice and have been with the company for a long time 
-Pay is competitive if you negotiate during hiring
cons:
Working at Qualcomm is like working for a dinosaur. It’s an older tech company, with the talent to match. It’s very different from any other tech company in that it moves like a dinosaur. Unqualified and ineffective leadership cling to their roles and enforce unnecessary approval hierarchies because it’s clear they wouldn’t be able to get a job anywhere else at this point in their careers. Think boomers who can’t rotate a PDF, yet keep 10 people in a meeting so someone can demonstrate for them how to do it. Managers aren’t given any training, and employees are told career development is their responsibility. 

If you just want a job you don’t need to care about, this is probably fine for you. But Qualcomm is where people’s dreams of career advancement and development go to die.

The team I was first put in had a super high turnover rate

headline: My experience at Qcom
pros:
- The products/solutions which Qcom develops are very impactful to the world in a good way.
- Big organizations and broad expertise, chance to develop tech skills bread/depth wise, if you are willing to put in extra effort to follow-up with fellow engineers (BTW Documentation sucks).
- San Diego is an awesome place to live.
cons:
- As mentioned earlier, documentation at Qcom sucks, you need to approach right people with right leverage and be very persistent, orelse you can't get things done on time.
- Qcom internal tools suck.
- If you have counterparts at different geo locations, work life could be difficult sometimes. While it's advantageous to have team spread out across multiple locations, it's very important have proper etiquette here.
- Annual review process sucks, I hate matrix organizations, there a line manager whom you don't work with but, he/she is responsible for AR and there is a functional manager whom you work with on daily basis. This structure is stupid, primarily used for shifting blames.

headline: mixed to bad for IT department, India
pros: pay, package, benefits, flexibility, job security, laid back environment, focus on innovation on engineering front, some of good HR policies, stock benefits. good CEO vision. 5G & IOT Pioneer.
cons:
No growth in IT.
Lot of internal politics. diversity of different ethnic group is reduced & became limited to all local regional employees. 
Hardly any IT employee retention policy.
No onsite travel !
No inter department change. You stuck up with same teams for years.
IT not upgrading tech stacks.
IT employees treated as second class citizens - due to Engineering driven company.
No CMMI processes followed at all. 
A lot of firing in IT on USA location  created a boundary of job security between USA & india employees.
New ideas never welcomed atleast on real job functions.
TEMP/ consultant employees must must avoid any lucrative offer. Hard to get permanent - believe me.

headline: Interesting work
pros:
Decent compensation, good communication, lots of smart people. I think there are pretty good opportunities to learn and move into new job opportunities, and we're creating and testing the next generation of technologies in the lab. That's pretty cool.
They actually fund R&D and don't seem to be cutting long term plans for short term profits. Wallstreet usually destroys larger engineering firms...
cons:
-The work life balance can be off. I think there is good flexibility, but a lot of pressure to work outside of normal hours/weekends.
-They implemented an "unlimited time off policy", but my VP was like "well, you can't have unlimited time off, so <5 years is 15 days etc, here's a PTO policy that doesn't accrue and we don't have to pay out."
-They are resisting fully remote work for most employees. It'll be interesting to see how this evolves.

cons:
The local management is excellent at trying to trick employees into thinking they are compensated well and learning a lot. Also they are not transparent.

No learning. Almost everything you do in Qualcomm Singapore is re-use from Qualcomm US. As such, there is no skill you are picking up. You will be in difficult situation with a lack of skills to move around, and suddenly in a position where there is too much to learn in too little time.

There is too much work, and the compensation is does not match that. 

Also, doing so much work, you will never have personal time to develop skills. And you are not going to develop any skills at work either. There are tools that are used (not developed by you), tests that are run (not developed by you), and data that is collected and shared to other teams (not analyzed by you).

Overall, if you are looking to learn, this is NOT the place to be.
Skills are very important, so dont expect to pick any here.

Last but not least, people tend not to share things with you, and that hinders progress. Not a collaborative environment, within teams. Across teams, it is collaborative, because the company cannot function otherwise.

headline: Excellent benefits, but somewhat overworked
pros:
- Excellent benefits such as an extremely well matched 401k, free healthcare, dental, vision
- Decent salary with yearly review
- Good company culture, good people, very little red tape compare to other companies
cons:
- Wage increases and bonuses are based off of an opaque algorithm (based off of inputs from your yearly review). Qualcomm simply offers you an increase off of this algorithm and does not allow you to negotiate at all.
- Qualcomm also gives out large sums of RSU’s instead of cash bonuses. This is supposed to incentivize you to stay with the company and work to increase the stock price, but ultimately it’s a way for them to have you chase a golden carrot for the rest of your career. You essentially lose large amounts of money if you end up quitting, and the value of your bonus is tied to the price of the stock which is subject to fluctuations in the stock market.
- It is unlikely for you to end up in a high level position as there are too many people at the company for substantial growth
- Qualcomm uses ancient custom software, and in general has a terrible development environment that makes the job unbearable
- Because of the bad development environment, a lot of the work ends up being administrative, rather than being
- Work-life balance can be out of whack depending on customer needs

headline: My unfiltered experience as CEO
pros: I was overpaid by a wide margin. Seriously, it had to be a computer error. I have no idea how I was even hired. I walked into their headquarter’s lobby to use the bathroom on my way to enlist in the Navy down the street, and I wound up running a logistics meeting for three members of the board forty minutes later. Crazy how a little bathroom chit-chat can change one’s life.
cons:
There are some real pieces of doo-doo still around from the old days. These people are still calling native americans “indians”. Get with the times, folks. 

Also, the company slashed my snack budget by 80% Yoy, and I’m obviously the one who approves the final budget (CEO). Somehow they still snuck that past me. I found that petty. Technically, it’s insubordination. And sure, I do have an affinity for rare juices that often times are flown in from abroad - but it’s super rare and classy juice. Basically an investment. I’m talking flavors of kool aid and capri sun you’ve never heard of, as they were never released to the public. Some billionaire russian oligarch bought the rights to these secretly flavored capri sun for his children, and capri sun corporate said, “heck yea, we’ll take the money up front, we’ll just give the public a clear version of fruit punch and call it a day”.
That’s the kind of juice I was getting my hands on. Collector level goods. And for my own colleagues to go behind my back and say, “No more fine-juices”… it feels like a knife to my heart. I still had enough of a budget to get a solid snack rotation in the works, but it was never the same as the good times: fine-juices on tap in my office, a few small chocolate fountains, and a 24/7 salad bar. Rarely used, but it definitely made me feel healthier just having it around. 

At the end of the day, the snack budget cuts killed my motivation to remain employed at Qualcomm. That, and they discovered I never graduated from college.

headline: RF360 subsidiary SME management
pros:
Experience legendary $10 increment although you are expected to work onsite even during the pandemic. 
Referral fee $300
Get to work in new big empty office building without proper office table and chair.
Train you to be independent to look for answer with zero guidance.
If you obtain M1/M2 it is a safe haven, just delegate the job, when anything screwed up just blame the engineers or technicians as they are replaceable.
cons: Default work onsite even if you don't need to be on-site everyday. Expected to work even you are on mc or doctor certified that you are unwell. Clock-in/out is closely monitored, if not punctual may deduct your salary. Toxic and incompetent management. No point getting to know your colleagues as the turn over rate is tremendously high compare to similar industries. Those managed to stay are in the good books of the respective bosses

headline: Cutting edge technology leader -- for the right reason
pros:
work with some of the best people in the industry.
lot of people with very inspiring go getter attitude.
good pay, good hike, good perks, good facilities.
flexibility to explore different technologies, teams, work profiles and geographical area.
Lot of people spend decades or beyond being in this company.
 a little more competitive environment but I will consider it on positive side (at least better then some semiconductors giants who has hired bunch of government employees)
relatively better job security compared to others in the industry.
This is one of the companies where people in head quarters listens to what Indians say at least partially.
cons:
salaries are good but not the best in the industry
sometimes work life balance goes for a toss, as the expectations is to be online and work more time. -- this is pretty much relaxed in covid times though.
too much influence from head quarters specially indians sitting in San Diago are making it nightmare for people working in India.
mid level management politics.

headline: Great for Hardworking Bootlickers
pros:
Overall compensation wise it's good. RSU grant significant enough to inflate your measly pay that if you've decide to leave the company, it'll hard to find match in a similar sector. 
Great Medical Benefits. Phone bill claim. No OT claim, but able to claim meal/Taxi.
A lot of leaves per year (>24 days), Vacation Match - you can convert your leave into pay.
cons:
Ever since Qualcomm's anti-trust lawsuit settlement with Taiwan. HQ is all in on accelerating the Taiwan's growth at the expense of Singapore workforce. Basically SG has been deprioritized, there's a doom and gloom atmosphere among SG employees and morale is low.

The company culture significantly rewards boot-lickers instead of actual expertise. A sycophant's paradise if you're looking to advance higher. It's pathetic seeing your colleagues trying so hard at bum-sucking and flatter everything their bosses say.

Don't expect work life balance. Nobody remembers or observes public holidays ever existed. Basically you're expected be available to work 7 days a week, and people bother you non-stop even you've clearly taken Annual Leave.

headline: The team was not a great team. Too much politics and organization is very heavy.
pros: San diego is a good place to live. Qualcomm is big tech employer.
cons:
Very heavy organization. More managers than the actual engineers to do job. The higher managers lacked knowledge and did not want to learn new things. Salary gap between male and female. 
This is the only place I have worked where engineers hesitate to share information with the team. May be due to individual office space culture.

headline: Toxic management during COVID-19
pros:
Helpful teammates and environment
Good work life balance
cons:
Things were great until the COVID-19 lockdown started.
All of the seniors/upper-management were allowed to leave for their hometowns, meanwhile juniors (Associate Engineers/Engineers) were refused to leave for their hometowns. The decision didn't make any sense at all as my team is purely software based, and hardware dependencies were already taken care of using remote access. Management failed to explain the decision and kept coming back with "HR policies must be adhered to". Same was the scenario throughout teams in the Hyderabad office. Given the difficult times and absence of amenities in a non-native city, this decision turned toxic for all of the juniors. An unfortunate and avoidable turn of events, especially in times like these.

headline: Qualcomm IT Review
pros:
Average compensation in IT. Other benefits are same across company and better than average. 
Most of the IT organization is a decent place to work and is providing advance technologies and services for rest of the company. 
Smart engineers across company.
cons:
***This review is only for IT***

IT is considered a cost center.
Lot of red tapes and burdensome processes which makes project delivery painful and long.
Most of the IT organization is a decent place to work but working in some of the groups within IT has been very toxic. Some of the managers are incompetent and seems to be out of place for the job. No or little communication from top to down leads to lot of confusion in project delivery. Lot of micromanagement, blame games, politics between teams rather than focusing on goals. Very aggressive deadlines, weekend deliveries with very little work life balance.

headline: Poor work life balance.  Watch your back.
pros: Depends on the group. Some groups work a lot harder, longer than others. For San Diego, a relatively stable employer.
cons:
Promotion and bonuses depend on who you know versus actual work. 
A great company under founder but with each new change in management team the company becomes less about innovation and more about executives maximizing their own wealth.
If you work within licensing business...the good life, collect checks, rest and vest. If you work in QCT, prepare for churn and burn. If you work in corporate, great if you like to take part in Life activities and have little to no motivation

headline: Doing well recently
pros: Working on cutting edge technologies. The culture allows everyone to work on what they are interested in. Compensation has been very good in recent years. Also, leadership is battle proven, and tested to be wise.
cons: What if Qualcomm loses Apple's market share because of Apple going vertical, or lose of market share in China due to geopolitics? These questions worry me some -- but the leadership seems to be optimistic, and I tend to trust them knowing they sailed the ship in through rougher waters in the past five years or so.

headline: Great employer
pros: They value their engineers and encourage contributions to their I.P., which is how it should be. It really was a great place to work while they had a large operation running here in Raleigh. They make sure their engineers all have a quiet place to work privately if they need to work by having offices and doors for most of their engineers above a certain level, yet also provide enough meeting rooms and common areas so that there is room for team discussions. It was a fun, great place to work, and a highlight of my career while I was there. The office building where I worked has been completely dismantled and no longer bears the Qualcomm logo.
cons: The only real downside is that if top management makes a poor business decision, which is something that every business faces from time to time, everyone suffers, but the bad stuff rolls downhill and the ones making the lousy decisions stay on, but thousands of others lose their jobs, which is what happened to my job and over a thousand others. That said, the company still took very good care of all of us and made sure we found work with a generous package, however, so Qualcomm really did show that they care about their people.

headline: Qualcomm is an exciting cutting-edge tech company to work for!
pros: I've had a great experience working at Qualcomm for over six years. It's exciting to work on technology used in almost every smartphone across the globe. There is always plenty of work to do, but in my experience I've always had the right amount of work and responsibility - not too much but not too little. The work-life balance is great for software developers.
cons: There is a lot to learn about wireless technology and modem software if you are joining with no experience in either. The learning curve is steep and for me it took years before I felt like I was actually becoming a solid individual contributor.

headline: Great apart from the workplace bullying

cons: One "leader" was a disgraceful workplace bully. He liked to take subordinates into 1-1s and yell at them so that other directors and senior leadership did not  find out. He was particularly aggressive to women and junior engineers and made their lives a misery. HR knows all about his behavior due to multiple complaints, but does absolutely nothing to rectify the situation and continues to move him to different roles across the company where his behavior continues. This is a shameful reflection on the company.

headline: A great place for technology

headline: The Pay Is OK - The Culture So Stale And Boring - Like "Death By A Thousand Needles" Boring
pros:
+ Remote work during covid
+ Pay is not bad in San Diego for software engineer (maybe top companies)
cons:
- Odds are you're likely going to work with many people on your team (if in engineering) that are intelligent (or at least enough to do their job with minimal assistance needed), but I have found many teams are comprised of conservative and boring people
- Upper Mgmt tends to blame their many ineptitudes on the lower ranks instead of taking responsibility for their unrealistic timelines which causes line managers to work their employees longer hours (working 50-65 hours a week [sometimes more if on the embedded or testing side of the house] is not uncommon even during COVID)

headline: Overall, a great company
pros:
As someone in the field of IT, Qualcomm is a great place to work overall. The company is massive and there's a lot of things to do and a lot of directions you can go. There's great great opportunity to learn and the company is definitely trying to keep up with latest trends; we are frequently among the first to try out new products and one of the earlier adopters of new protocols and technologies out in the field. If you truly enjoy what you are doing and want to get ahead, Qualcomm definitely provides you with the tools to do so. 

Recent reorg in IT has made work-life balance better, and the shift to a flexible work schedule seems to be permanent, which is awesome.

Decent benefits.
cons:
Overall compensation is a bit below market rate for the region, though pay increases the past few years have been well above average, maybe a result of the company settling the lawsuit with Apple and prevailing over the FTC.

The large scale of the company and it's monolithic structure can be frustrating at times to deal with. Sometimes difficult to find out who is in charge of what. Work sometimes gets bogged down as there can be many groups that require approval to implement. Large size of teams sometimes allow situations where certain employees can get away with doing bare-minimum work while others pick up the burden. The term "rest-and-vest" is used derisively here, and many employees are just waiting to retire.

headline: Fantastic company, visionary leadership
pros: At Qualcomm, everyone is dedicated to shaping the future of computing and communications. The salespeople are selling, today, chips that will be on devices 1-3 years in the future. Everyone else is designing and shaping the technologies that will use mainstream 3-10 years in to the future and beyond. It was a privilege to be part of that team and contribute to the world connectivity.
cons: You will need the ability to build your own track if you want to move ahead. The company is built around loooong career tracks (10 years+) and is not really well suited for today's high-ambition + high-potential that don't have the drive to build their own ways.

headline: Freshers (Caution)
pros:
No pros for a fresher except their mid-day free lunch. 

If you join as a fresher, assume your life is doomed ( They will take your confidence away. And make you feel like a slave in addition to the hostile environment they provide to you). If you want to join in this company, you better have an experience of 2-3 years and take their senior engineer role. Don't ever take their 'Engineer' or 'Assosciate Engineer' designation

Now, If you think I am writing this only because of my poor academic profile or having one bad experience in the company. Remove that from your mind. I cracked JEE with a rank below 500(gen. category), and I am one of the topper in my batch during my stay in IIT. And in Qualcomm, I worked in one of the best team (which is a emerging). I have been a crucial cog for some time as well.
cons:
Caution(freshers -don't join): Don't sway away by their no. 1 position in the processor market
"From 'making freshers feel hostile or not fit for the role given' to 'giving lots of work on a single day expecting to be like a senior'" - They do all these to a fresher.

Now, I am writing this only to caution freshers. They have zero tolerance to you, and once they feel you are lagging in some topic, they have this culture to not assign the work that you are lagging(they don't make you learn. Instead, they expect you to not lag every day, even if you are sick. And you need to fake if you want to be successful). Once they feel that you are bound to move out of the company, even-though it's after an year(u r thinking to move), they stop giving you work and make you feel stupid to be in the company. 

They will treat freshers with no respect. They will make freshers work like a slave (just like the ancient feudal system, here leads and managers are feudal lords and their juniors are their workers, who are bound to work for their lords). 

Freshers don't stay in this company for more than 2 years. They will get zero knowledge about the industry, if managers feel the fresher is bound to leave in such a manner(Managers will somehow make sure of this by not exposing you to the state-of-the-art). You need to be a fake of yourself to survive in this place (ironically, HRs want employees to be themselves and not a fake). You need to make your manager believe that you will stay in this company for your life-time(literally, lifetime). You need to fake in every meeting that you have understood the presenter's theory. If you question them, if he is your senior, then he will get angry and not give you work. Upper manager don't take you or your work or your ideas seriously. They make you feel you deserve a low-grade work and will take your confidence away.

I have experienced everything from being a worthless cog to becoming a crucial cog and again becoming a wortheless cog in the team after a while due to some personal reasons. But, one thing I can say is that I faked every minute, every day in this company, and faking in this company is taken as a success trait (for all the employees). As a fresher, my ideas were questioned in an illogical way by my seniors. Though after a while, they implemented the idea, my lead took the credit for implementing it (such an inhumane political act. The culture in this company itself is more political than hardwork. 

Company lives on hard-workjng people, but gives credit to political people ( from money to power). They will say they are crediting the management, because they are the one's who manages you. And you need to fake that you are in a complete agreement with this view.

I once again urge freshers(especially IITians) to not join this company. Along with your overall confidence and self-respect, you will also lose your health and will be prone to some life-style diseases (Such a hostile culture for an immature fresher).

headline: Avoid voice & music group (CSR)
pros: Brand Name and Competitive compensation
cons:
Most of the senior folks are incompetent and not good technically - thus make poor decisions and plans -- all are from CSR times having spend >10yrs. They just dump loads of work on junior engineers. No vision and roadmap whatsoever.
No Project management/Scrum followed which makes the project execution highly inefficient.
Almost Nil chances of growth. Favoritism plays a crucial role.
Nil Work life balance. Only join if you are willing to work 24x7 ("weekends and holidays included")
Team Leads/Managers don't encourage participation in tech trainings/sessions organized by the company.
Not open for suggestions/feedback.

If you are involved in a project on which the San Diego engineers are also working, then you'll need to work during your office hours and also be available during their office hours i.e. our night time. Hectic project schedule also means that you need to close on technical issues immediately and don't get any time to investigate these issues in-depth to increase your technical knowledge. Overall, forget about having a healthy and balanced lifestyle if you're working in this company.

headline: Very comfortable job but no motivation to work very hard
pros:
Easy and flexible work hours. No pressure.
Great travel and benefits. Very loose reimbursement policy.
Loved independence as worked from home most days. Most of office able to work from home. 
Paid more than QCT peers and buddies but work much less. 20% more. Too good to be true at times.
Loved San Diego.  perfect environment if you have family.
cons:
Lots of bureaucracy. So slow for us to move  to get deals done.   
Everyone who was good at QCV moved on to better jobs and funds.  No one really left who I  respect.
New leadership really lazy and can't make decisions. Very very slow.
Review process was demoralizing.  Hated it.
Loads of politics and backstabbing. Just ignore and you will be fine.  But dont expect help.

headline: Worst interview experience
pros: The building looked nice and the receptionist was very kind.
cons: I feel obligated to post this as it's still on my mind. I interviewed for Qualcomm over a year ago in their cambridge office. The interview was with 3 people, 2 of which were nice however the mid-level interviewer was incredibly rude to me. I was  nervous and struggled to answer questions I usually know the answer to and I was ordered around in ways such as "sit down." "Dont say anything." To make matters worse, at the end of that stage of the interview, the interviewer asked me my ethnic origin and also mocked my credentials as a junior at the time. Overall my worst interviewing experience.

headline: Engineer
pros: Flex-time off policy and some smart engineers
cons:
Talent isn’t appreciated in this company at all. It’s a very political place, with a lot of political power given to directors of groups. So if your director is good, you can get better salary, better bonuses and timely promotions.
If your director isn’t good, good luck getting promoted even to senior engineer (btw promotion = 10k salary increase, which is way too small).

If you are in remote site (not in SD that is), good luck with finding opportunities for career growth within the company. Utterly disgraceful management, with loads of VPs reporting each other, who do nothing valuable for growth of this company. Upper management doesn’t really care for even basic needs of engineers (like monumental pay increase, creating work-friendly environment). Review system is biased and managers don’t really care about third party opinions (why even take them, if you don’t care about them?)

There are better companies out there. Avoid like plague.

headline: Work-life balance over salary
pros: Great work-life balance at entry-level.  You get to work with the best of the best when it comes to IC design. Work hours are reasonable, and I rarely see anyone being too stressed about work hours at least in IC design team.
cons:
As you become more senior and lead a project, you need to have meetings with other parts of the world and often times, this means meeting at 10 pm. Also, the amount of meetings that managers have is often quite a lot which led many senior staff level engineers to quit and move to other companies.

Also, total compensation package is not very competitive compared to the competitors. This also often causes staff and senior staff engineers to quit and seek for better compensation.

Overall, a great company to learn the trade then move onto the better paying company.

headline: Not bad, but not as good as it used to be
pros: It's a pleasure to work with some of the smartest people I've ever met. In general, I have access to the tools I need to do my job, and to resources to keep my skills up to date. Management is sort of trying again to make it a good place to work.
cons:
Communication and Vision from senior leadership in the engineering organization is severely lacking.
The tools and processes engineers must deal with on a daily basis are a source of frustration.
Legal woes have been a constant overhang on employee morale (and compensation) for the last several years... and it seems it's still not finished.
Management is clumsily re-learning how to show their appreciation for employees by inviting thousands of employees to a launch party on one of the campuses  where we get to wait in horribly long lines just to get a free taco and a beer. Employee appreciation is nothing like what it used to be.
HR keeps fiddling with the performance review process and rating system, yet at the end of it all the rating system and forced curve-fitting ends up destroying employee morale even further.

headline: Tech Dinosaur

Company has lot a lot of talent and knowledge. Location isn't great for most people in SD due to traffic.

headline: Software Engineer
pros:
1. Benefits like free meals 3 times (giving 2 rating just because of it :P).
2. Company stocks program.
3. Most of the time work life balance is there.
cons:
1. Too much politics (south vs north) and (senior vs junior).
2. Working with old people is quite difficult, They don't encourage to think new or do something out of box.
3. Pay is well below market standard.
4. Managers are worst here, don't care about work ethics (can shout at anyone in work hours).
5. The process of norms is too much lengthy. So, work efficiency gets affected.
6. No clear division of work among engineers.
7. Scope of learning is very less and learning rate will become 0 after 1 year(same repetitive work again and again).
8. I worked in a team which was full of seniors people only and when i joined i was fresher so, they don't used to consider us as a significant resource.

headline: Proud employee
pros: Qualcomm has faced many challenges over the past years that could have been devistating for the company, but we stood together, executed and persevered! cons: Those challenges have made some people lose trust, but I think we've been able to regain some of it. Compensation is still something that needs to be addressed.

headline: Great company to fulfill your career aspirations
pros:
Free Breakfast and Lunch (though food quality is horrible most of the time)
Most of the technical leaders are extremely skilled and talented. 
Some of the software teams have very good work
Software teams have a good work-life balance
No micro management at many levels in software teams
Payscale is competitive as compared to the market
Good amount of shares given to employees based on performance
Really like the company's vision in bringing cutting edge innovations to the market
IT Department is very good. They always try to resolve any software and hardware issues at the earliest. A much-needed thing in any large company.
Great scope to turn ideas into inventions.Management and tech leads are very supporting on filing these ideas.
cons:
Human resource and facilities departments are quite disappointing. They function just like government departments. 
Milestone Recognition awards are disappointing in terms of reward amounts. (5/10/20 yr anniversary awards for example)
Off late, some of the employee-friendly policies have been removed (car lease policy). Updated weird snack top-up policy (the top up lapses every Friday if not used. Earlier it was quarterly)
Its been ages it made into the best companies to work for India due to some of the above cons

headline: Zero career growth, stifling  culture
pros:
If you were part of the founding team 15 years ago, this place is for you!  You will be rewarded royally, you will approve each others patents, you will work on v1000 of the same boring design.

If you have no career aspirations, this place is also for you! You can sit back, push pencils, and enjoy the decent salary and health insurance.
cons: Everyone else, need not apply.   This is no place to build a career.  You will be pigeonholed.  You won't be challenged.  Good work is not rewarded.  Good ol boys network galore.

headline: A dinosaur on the verge of extinction
pros: San Diego is one of the finest cities
cons:
Old in every sense of the word.
Average age close to 40. Most people still program in C exclusively. Outdated organization - 3 people (system + software + test engineer) doing the job of 1 software engineer in silicon valley. Same business model from the 90s. Technology hasn't changed since 4G - 5G is just smoke and mirrors, and upper management doesn't know how to run anything else.

headline: Used to be great, now random unannounced layoffs
pros:
Flexable hours
Can work from home when needed
'unlimited vaction' good if decent tech lead
Covers all health care premiums
Always something interesting to work on
ESPP 15% discount up to 15% of salary
Promotion opportunity up to Senior Staff
cons:
Last 2 rounds of layoffs not even announced.
Management even denied layoffs days before
RSU now only for top performer (was 6-10%)
Bonuses were 12%+, past 5 years about 6%
Stock same price as 11 years ago. 
All internal tools are now horrible cause they either fired the teams that made them or fired everyone but one or two people to support the defunct tools.
Any promotion above Senior Staff requires "Business Need"
They usually require 3 years in a position before promotion
Any slight rating drop in a performance review can push your promotion out a few years. Don't wait just get a new job and come back for a promotion.
If your tech manager is good you're fine. If they're horrible you're screwed get a new one immediately.
Check if your team has counterparts in India. Most teams do. If yours does that means you will have 9am meeting and much more often meetings/debug sessions between 9pm and midnight.

headline: Traditional environment, Good people, Interesting work
pros: Qualcomm invests in creating new things, so there are lots of opportunities to create. The environment is what I would call "traditional corporate". You don't have free lunches or on-site massage like the dot coms, but you do have private offices with doors that can close!
cons: The drawback is that Qualcomm best understands radio, and the modem-side of the house gets all the love. If you're on another technology and thongs are going well then you'll be supported. However, when tightening hits it will be your project on the block because the radio is where it's at.

headline: Qualcomm is a great place to work
pros:
1. Get to work on the latest technology
2. Good compensation
3. Good knowledge base, you will be working with the team who knows about the IP end to end, if lucky with the original designers
4. Food, cafeteria, team outing, nice office buiding, gym, year-end gifts etc
cons:
1. Work-life balance, there will be tons of works. I guess good compensation comes at the cost of this huge workload
2. The learning and exploration are on your own, you can't expect any training/hand holding. You have to be responsible for your own learning and ramp up. At times you'll have to work while ramping up, you'll have to work extra hours during that time.
3. Expect to work from day one.

headline: Dynamic Working Environment
pros:
Being a Market leader in the fast paced semiconductor industry, Qualcomm is a very dynamic organization. 
You get to work on Cutting-Edge and Next Gen technologies. 
You get to work with some of the best minds and smartest people in the industry.
The compensation and benefits are some of the best in the industry as well which definitely helps.
cons: Due to stringent delivery timelines, work load can sometimes be very stressful. The industry being so dynamic, expects you to be on your toes all the time.

headline: Not the same company it once was

headline: Better than other places but sliding downhill
pros: Working with some of the most talented people in the industry raises the bar and challenges you to be the best you can be. So much to learn working here. Salaries are generally competitive (but changing).  Depending on your manager, you can have flexibility in your work hours. On-site health care is convenient and high quality.
cons:
Benefits shrinking rapidly — no more accrued vacation time. Also, with repeated layoffs and understaffed departments, it’s near Impossible to find a time “convenient to the business” to take any time off.   Headcount is cut in half in some areas while workload only grows, and there is no concern for employee welfare and how to resolve tired over-worked  employees having unrealistic workload to manage. New merit review system removes manager ability to individually reward high performers (it is all decided by compensation team).  High performers are given minuscule salary increases below cost of living increase; how does this
motivate anyone? No end in sight to mountains of work growing with no plans to add resources, only more reductions.

headline: Used to be great, going through difficult times
pros: Professional work environment. Health plan is fully paid by employer. Good 401k matching with incentive to maximize contributions. A decent ESPP is available for employees. Good charity matching programs.
cons: Flexible Time off policy means obtaining vacations will become difficult as they are subject to approval. Decline in stock value means retention RSUs aren't really worth a whole lot compared to rest of industry. Signing bonuses can easily outmatch retention awards. Many employees have left as a result and will continue to leave. Company no longer has a strong technology advantage in comparison to competitors. Management may be making poor decisions due to misaligned interests. Litigation with major customer has been very costly for company.

headline: Senior director
pros: Brilliant people drive themselves to win, and the company won big over decades.  Priceless experience you can't get elsewhere.  Launching technology around the world, and changing the world in a big way.
cons: Unfortunately morale has gone down over the past couple years.  Quite a bit in 2018, after some significant layoffs.  You will work long hours, but it's been that way for decades.  Expect that in any tech company these days.  All this "work life balance" stuff you see is not true - anywhere.   Tech advances more rapidly year over year.  If you are excited about the work and fruits of the company's labor, you don't think so much about the balance.  That's the way it was until a couple years ago.   Now it's more thinking about the balance and if you really want to continue working there.   Ratings in all categories below would be higher if rated 2+ years ago.

headline: Alas, not the great company that it used to be

cons: The atmosphere no longer feels like a family like it did when the Jacobs family was calling the shots. The primary focus seems to be on the stock price, rather than on innovation. headline: Hemorrhaging good talent
pros: Fast-paced, interesting work. It's cool to be able to point to a phone and say "I helped make that." Really fun technical problems, engaging challenges, and lots of intelligent people to work with. Good opportunities for learning and growth, though dependent on where you are in the company. The pay is great, though the benefits have been declining slowly, but overall compensation is pretty good.
cons:
When I started at Qualcomm, they were on the Forbes Top 100 Companies to work for list. They haven't been back since, and it's clear why: they stopped treating their employees as a valuable asset, and instead seem to be treating them as expendable assets. I've watched almost half my team go to other companies, but no one in management seems to be panicking like they should be.

Qualcomm seems to have no common processes, nor the flexibility to let small groups decide their own processes. "Agile" and "Scrum" are words that are used without any of the actual benefits of those processes. The inefficiency in my group alone is staggering, and proposing improvements gets opposition from the 10+ year veterans who think they're still working at a scrappy startup company. 

Which leads to the other thing: Qualcomm is an enormous company with tons of revenue, but there are still, for some reason, pockets of the company (or maybe it's universal, for all I know) that act like it's a startup where everyone needs to put in ridiculous hours all the time. If Qualcomm can't meet their deadlines with people working normal hours, then that's a management issue, not employees not working hard enough. There are times when long hours over a short, pre-determined period can result in huge efficiency gains, and that can be worth it. But when it's considered a negative on your performance  review that you're unavailable on weekends, while the rest of your work is stellar... well, it makes sense that people (those who could) would try to find a more sane work environment.

headline: Poor senior management, onerous open source processes, process heavy
pros:
Your experience may vary widely by division, but in general some things are done well:
Automatic header files from RTL
Capital expenditure for HW, SW, FPGA emulation
Automatic build, boot, some CI infrastructure
cons:
QCT specially is very process heavy
QC just lost its entire custom CPU core team after they bungled the Datacenter division: huge blunder for a chip company to lose its entire custom CPU team.. bleeding talent right now
Core teams do work, and then there are root teams per customer
A lot of QCT firmware teams don't like to adopt standards/open source software
Linux development is very process heavy with small things needing legal approval
Management was great under founders, but progressively losing its way: current "leaders" are in panic mode and if they go down route of 30 billion dollars buy backs, that's the beginning of the end
Even after layoffs, still a lot of fat in SD, lots of layers of mgmt, too many status collectors

headline: Qualcomm is a great company in a perfect storm
pros: Qualcomm has amazing technology that's truly unmatched by any other would-be in the industry. It's spirit of innovation upon which it was founded still resides with many of the employees, especially at headquarters. It continues to be the leader in mobile technologies--modems and connectivity like 3G, 4G and the coming 5G. Qualcomm treats its employees very well and is generous in terms of salary and benefits.
cons: The company is in a bit of turmoil due to the on-going external attacks regarding its Licensing business, which delivers the lion's share of the company's profitability. In addition, te on-going delay in the acquisition of NXP, which was to help the company expand its footprint and TAM, has slowed the company's momentum. Note that the delay was due not to the company's short-comings, but by international politics, as China is the one remaining region to approve the acquisition. This challenge, combined with the on-going lawsuits over its licensing practices with Qualcomm's leading customer, Apple, has blended into a difficult, perfect storm for the management team.

headline: Avoid This  Sinking Ship
pros: 1.  Pay is above average for the area & benefits are comprehensive.
cons:
1.  Incredibly political atmosphere fosters hostility and resentment among employees.  Many of the "Qualcomm lifers" are there to "rest and vest" and are incredibly resentful of newcomers.
2.  Extremely top heavy company with excessive amounts of upper management who expect the few non-management employees to do all of their work for them with no assistance, or guidance.  Many Managers, Directors and VPs have no direct reports, and many departments have more management-level employees than not.
3.  The company panders to the short-term whims of their investors, at the long-term cost of the company.  One only needs to look at the on-going "cost reduction initiative" to save $1 billion to realize this.  The company announced the initiative a few days before being slapped with around $1 billion in regulatory fines.  Instead of adjusting their business model to prevent even further regulatory damages (QC has been slapped with major fines by Korea, China, and the EU to name a few), they insist on continuing with their controversial business model and instead choose layoff thousands of employees once more.  Additionally, as part of the initiative there are no opportunities for internal transfers resulting in a mass exodus of much of the company's young, top talent.

The bottom line:  I had high hopes for this company when I first started.  Unfortunately, Qualcomm is a sinking ship.  It's only a matter of time before all of their top young talent leave for another company that will do right by it's employees and investors, a company with a sustainable vision for the future, in addition to equitable pay.

headline: Don't join Qualcomm
pros: SoCal weather which has nothing to do with the company
cons: work culture is dominated by politics and backstabbing.  good engineers get pushed out, bad ones get promoted.  technical depth is getting shallower and shallower.  nepotism and favoritism from your manager is the only key to success.  This company is going through a reverse evolution.  it will be a disaster if you join now, especially young fresh graduates.

headline: Staff Engineer
pros: Great co-workers, smart and hard working.
cons: Executive management is not great,  planning is done so poorly that they will severely under staff SoC projects and engineers will work round the clock most of the time  including most weekends to try to make deadlines. There is a significant need for process improvement as one team works on one block and there is little communication or overlap so there are so many issues. They just let go of a lot of the people that were trying to fix this issue so it is not going to improve. This last round(s) of lay offs were not low performers as they have been in past. There were a very high  number of people who were recently promoted and or I know were getting 6/7's ie outstanding reviews and high performers and were working weekends and all hours like most of us. It was a wake up call that performance or even how much your job is needed has no impact that you can be cut to make wall street and executives happy - so the loyalty factor myself and other team members who know we can easily get other jobs have stayed but a lot of people if they are not on visas or other significant reason to stay are looking.   It used to be a great place to work but last few years sicne Steve took his 96 million or some added stock bonus on top of his existing stock and bonus's when we were all told that ear that stock grants and bonus's would be lower and we had lay offs things have gone down hill fast. We always worked hard but now they expectation is to work much harder for fewer raises/lower bonus. There is no longer any worklife balance and everyone is stressed and people who are not complainers are starting to complain this year they cant possibly get done what has been assigned so its constant stress.    I know 2 people who were asked to take a demotion and pay cut to save their job (not due to performance again these are high performers) they both asked their director and Sr director respectively if they were taking a demotion or pay cut the answer was no - then how can you ask your staff to!!!! I feel for new people coming in as moral is at an all time low

headline: Poor leadership, poor outlook
pros:
Engineering teams can be filled with great and friendly people. Like at most jobs, your experience will depend on your team.

For the most part, there's a good work/life balance. Working 9-5 and sometimes 9-6 is typical.
cons:
* Major layoffs in 2015 and again in 2018. I survived both but it makes you question the leadership.
* Stock price is less now than when I started 3 years ago and the outlook is not great. This is at a time when the stock market, and tech stocks specifically, are soaring. Negotiate your sign-on bonus in cash so it doesn't lose value before vesting.
* There is no company culture. Leadership doesn't instill any values or motivation. The CEO only ever says "we are going to be the leaders in 5G".

headline: Not good for freshers esp. for software development
pros:
Still has good name in industry. Good if you want to god for further education.
Good benefits. Gym and Insurance.
Pay is bit less but ok. Esp if you are in ECE domain. Not for CSE guys.
cons:
Hyderabad has mostly grunt mindless work. Makes company look like a glorified services company. Very few teams have work which is good for your career enhancement and being put in that team depends mostly on luck.
Freshers from the best Indian colleges are put in random projects. Ppl who were good at programming in college are put in teams where minimal technical challenges are there.
Team specific training is almost non-existent. Lack of proper documentation about processes. Seniors are happy to just complete their work and don't care about freshers. Either you will be given ridiculous amount of work with no training, or you will be given no work at all many days as seniors are busy in just handling all themselves and don't care about freshers gardual learning growth.
Most freshers stay only for 1-2 years because of this messed up work culture. If you are talented and hungry for challenging problems(regardless of hw/sw domain) this is not the place for you. You can search on linkedin how long freshers stay here.
Middle managers are mostly incompetent. Zero feedback mechanism from freshers. Any feedback given is just thrown away and not acted upon.
You should be very lucky to have a good team/good mentors here.

headline: Qualcomm San Diego
pros: In terms of benefits Qualcomm is excellent. Free gym, good 401k match, good pay, decent bonuses and stock options, excellent health care (free), many employee programs, lots of tech training, nice campus, onsite cafeterias - you name it.
cons: The company is a dinosaur. The management structure is deep with many redundant levels and political power structures. Decisions are not made for technical reasons but rather to benefit your Director or VP. There are periodic layoffs that tend to hit the lowest performers first, but they also lay off those who do not "fit in" (ie. anyone who actually has good ideas and is somewhat vocal.) Job performance is increasingly about perception rather than results. Career advancement varies great between departments. If you are lucky enough to have a benevolent manager you'll get promoted every few years, if you have a bully you'll be forever stuck in the same role (ie. 10 years or more) since you're not deemed worthy despite all your excellent reviews. Qualcomm could easily reduce headcount by 75% and still keep their core businesses: Modem and MSM. They are and old, slow, flabby company that is only focused on cost reduction rather than innovation.

headline: Senior GPU Verification Engineer
pros: Location: San Diego is one of the best location you can work in US.
cons:
GPU is probably the worst department in Qualcomm headed by bunch of clowns. Promotion is only given to sycophants. Unless you are close the the small circle which controls the department, you stand no chance. People in this circle are one of the dumbest in the industry who will eventually blame their failure (almost every project is a certain failure) on employees.  Annoyingly, You will always be compared against these people by your manager.

Managers are the worst, at times abusive. Outright liars.
If you are on immigration , STAY AWAY: Every single day your manager will remind of the HUGE favor done to you by filing your immigration.

After all the mental tortue you get every week, your pay is one of the lowest in semiconductor industry.

writing for the Bangalore vlsi office:
good place to see multiple variety of chip design projects & industry practices
dynamic env at work
cons:
the politics in the mid level staff is horrific
projects are very similar & repeat a lot, this leads to managers expecting quicker results. The focus is on the finishing the work & passing the parcel than resolving the issue. Due to this the Bangalore office is not trusted with premium tier chips by San-diego. This is unlikely to change until quality/processes are setup to meet standards.
the HR folks rarely care once the employee is hired
work-life balance sucks but ppl compromise it for getting double digit appraisal

headline: Modem system test engineer
pros:
Stressful environment make you learn very fast (yes, I like to work hard and learn fast.); 
Used have lots of exceptional lead can teach you not only in tech but also in how to do things in engineer way, especially those system team engineer before 2008. That's the best work experience I ever have.
Used have lots of access to design documents,  if you are just graduated, this is a great book to understand how everything you learned in course can combine together.
Qualcomm benefits and salary is not that bad, if you just need and job to stay in US or have good quality life, it is a good choice.
cons:
MST is not a high tech group since it is doing testing, so it is less chance for promotions and high chance when company needed to layoff some people. Especially company is focusing on delay people's promotion and testing jobs are transfer to Inida now, so be wise to make your choices. 
Performance review is pretty much not working, from my experience, hardworking year's rating is lower as I just finish my job (because I stay in current  group longer in next review....), the rating is highly related to how long you been in your group. But, if you finish your job as the way your manger wanted and have strong technology. Maybe can be faster....
Since job is not hard to finish, so politic come into the working environment which make promotion and performance rate more confusing. 
Engineer minds is keep reducing in this group.
Under pay for sure and company's management team could tell you in department all-hands meeting that multiple finance model proved salary is competitive.
Since Qualcomm is under paying, talented people are leaving.

headline: Not it used to be
pros: Qualcomm had a good run when the smart phones and individual devices were on the boom.  Now it is changing.
cons: People show their true colors in crisis, and the same goes with the company.  Some of the junior and mid layer managers have been in the company just long enough that they cannot move up or out.  They are trying to cling on with *all* they have.  Their bosses sees what's happening but decides to turn a blind eye.  This has made it very difficult for the staff.  Because instead of empowering the staff to achieve their best performance, the staff are being used as pawns to grab more project, or show more results than the other manager.  The dotted line management and reporting structure has also made it confusing for the staff when support/help is needed.

headline: No Value for Employees
pros:
* Compensation comparable to market
* Quite relaxed work culture

If you are thinking of retirement, could be one of the best but not for new job seekers.
cons:
Many:
* Management is rigid in assigning projects to new comers. If you are a fresh graduate, don't expect to get on a project of your choice or matching skills.
* No values for past employees. I did my undergrad internship, 2 year full time in India and then grad internship in SD and at the end, didn't received my full time offer. Even after good work, manager review and a patent application out of my intern work.
* HR is not very helpful. When I was not selected, my HR didn't even had the audacity to inform me and kept me hung. I came to know from a 2nd HR but already a lot of time had been wasted
* During my full time in India, I kept asking for a project/team which suits my skills and  area of interest, but they were like, we can't.

headline: A Fantastic Company for the Engineers
pros:
Qualcomm is one of the best paymaster company's in India. In the early stages, they were treating employees like anything till the business gets stiff. They were investing in employees heavily. Some of the benefits and perks were below.

 - Excellent Compensation
 - RSU and ESOP
 - Free Food
- Performance Bonus
- Travel
- Training
- Reimbursement Policy (Mobile Handset, Gym, Personal)

Apart from the benefits, you get to work on the cutting edge technology which will be immense help from your learning aspect.
cons: At times when business is not functioning well, you may have to suffer from the cost cutting as well as layoff as well.  Apart from those long working hours and high-pressure job.

headline: Great Company - Undervalued
pros: Another US based company with same achievements would have leveraged the success much better than Qualcomm did. But it is also true it is one of the most gentlemanly company in US today. The management is candid and try to be honest. The compensation is above average. The quality of work is above average for most.  At least until very recently there was a sense of purpose - bigger than thy  - culture of excellence in hardware design.  Although the floodgate of lay off has opened two years back - company is still one of the best in the world.
cons:
Two main problems:
1. As the company is now middle aged - it is top heavy. At Staff and Sr. Staff Level opportunity of growth (in terms of quality and breadth of work) is getting limited by days. The attrition and frustration is increasing by days. Not long ago, about 5 years ago employees who went gaga about Qualcomm and were irritably proud and short sighted (most folks here only worked in Qualcomm and no other companies, possibly 80% of engineering workforce) about Qualcomm's achievement are now growling about almost everything. 

This is because of #2.

2. Company is trying to break free of its dependency on phone/modem business. Until that happens and revenue stream start to show that this phase will last.

headline: The company has no vision, with the very top execs making the most profits before it collapses
pros:
-Still one of the better benefits among the companies in San Diego
-Lots of talented people (though most who were smart enough, or could, have already left)
cons:
Reeks of greed. CONSTANT downgrades in everything compared to what it was in the last 10 years... from the quality of toilet paper, removal of reverse osmosis water filters, health plan, Qualstar ($100 peer rewards down to $50), removing access to JCC gyms, charging $4 monthly for 401K, canceling end-of-the-year parties, etc.
The IT department at Qualcomm used to be world-class. They've outsourced it and nowadays it's a total waste of time; "let me research that" is a typical answer when you ask IT a question - total waste of resources. Laptop refreshers take 5+ years and engineers get stuck with old, outdated equipment. CEO & Jacobs each took $59 million in bonus a few years ago when employees were getting laid off. HR typically shows you their middle finger if you ask for a market adjustment (I'm at 92% according to them, and I asked for one - they gave me %0.1 raise ... yes, that's tenth of 1 percent). Initially when they downgraded the health plan a few years ago, the physical flyers that were mailed to us read something along the lines of "the details of your health plan UPGRADE"... downright twisted. All that said, HR is making promotions beyond Staff level very difficult to impossible - good luck with that career growth if you join

headline: Staff hardware Engineer
pros:
Very nice and friendly colleagues and managers, very easy to communicate and offer help when needed.
Great benefits, especially the health plan
cons:
Poor work- life balance, too much work on too few resources’ shoulder. People are leaving, at least partially due to the large amount of work, endless meeting, late night conference calls and etc. Meeting scheduled for 1 or 2 hour usually ends up taking more than four hours in the evening time with Asian team. Don’t expect to take fallibly responsibility such as pick up kids from school and etc if you work in the hardware ( especially the chip) team.

When people are leaving, no new resource is in and the people retain has more in his plate, until he got burn out and also decides to leave, this forms a poor loop..

Too complicated design flow. Even re-use an IP and doesn’t make any change, the long checking list from design review is impossible to finish during normal hours, not talking about new IP development. Mid management continues to add items on the checking list to address new poped up bugs in product, without adding new resource, they just want to make sure new items are added that can catch the bug, don’t care how much more execution work added on engineers. And they don’t ever consider some items on the check list is not necessary and can be removed/replaces by the new added ones. The results are the list getting longer and longer, engineers who execute the work are more and more overloaded, until burn out.

Compensation is, if not poor, at least not good. Compensation is competitive if compared with average semiconductor industry, but since Qualcomm looks itself as tier one semiconductor company, HR should compare the compensation with top companies such as Apple, Broadcom, TI and etc. Before joining QCOM, I worked for another large IC company in a low cost state, my first year package after graduation is more than the first year at Qcom, when I already have couple years experience. Ironic, right? At 2015 year end, after one year hard working, bonus is only 3 digit number, yes, you read correctly... this is in San Diego, a high living cost place.

headline: Worst company if you want to learn and keep growing your skills
pros:
Actually present environment has changed much. Now Qualcomm is also like other medium paying companies. 
Pros - 
1. you can file your ideas in portal and if it's unique company will apply for a patent grant and you will get some benefit as well.
2. 110 rs. daily free food
3. Adequate medical insurance
4. Team outings
cons:
1. Bureaucracy and politics
2. Management is so crude and no matter how talented you are and how much you work. They will promote you only after completing 3 years and more.
3.   Yearly review cycle and that's also not sure how much hike you will get as it depends on overall earnings which are shrinking year by year in competitive mobile chipset market.
4. Huge work load. you take one week leave and management thinks you were not working from last 6 months.
5. Learning areas are very shrink and regular work load is more. which will make you tire and unfit to outside world job market.
6. Most of the teams has no coding work, So you will forget all the programming knowledge and while looking for new job, you will have to study all your programming basics again.
7. Telugu speaking people are benefited specially in Hyderabad location

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Top notch talented engineers!  Pleasant work environment with an open attitude.  If you want to discuss something with the VP, just drop by his office.  Your opinion counts, and you can make real changes.  In Boulder, there is on-site gym and cafeteria, and other amenities.  The work is leading-edge wireless tech, and there is a wide variety of projects at the Boulder office.
cons: Since the incredible success of smart phones, there has been an increasing pressure to just "turn the crank" to churn out minor/no modifications to software and hardware for follow-on ASICs.  The organization has grown and been compartmentalized such that it can be difficult to be "a star" in the crowd (but the opportunity still exists).

headline: Not a company I'd recommend working for
pros: Decent 401k and benefits. On-site gyms, on-site food services, most buildings are clean and modern. Industry standard vacation/holiday/sick time.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy, favoritism, and inflated job titles. Performance reviews are twice a year with a quota system that limits the # of employees per dept who can get favorable reviews/rankings, which causes poor teamwork and very unhealthy competitiveness among employees since everyone wants to get the top ranking--raises occur only during one of the two review cycles. Taking sick time seems to be widely frowned upon, so it's best to take zero sick days--sick time is sometimes used to ding a person on performance reviews.

headline: Do not pursue employment at Qualcomm
pros: Past reputation.  If you enjoy spending 50% of your time in conference rooms without windows that smell of mold filled with broken stained chairs and tables that are falling apart - this is your company!  Company looks great from afar but once you actually start working it's a different story.
cons:
Qualcomm will own you.  They will state in your legal documentation that you are free to do what you want on your own time as long as it doesn't conflict with Qualcomm business but if you do you will be fired without notice.  Qualcomm wants you to be Innovative, but if you do so on your free time, they will fire you for even working on a simple free app for a cell phone that has nothing to do with their business.  

Their pay is low and their health insurance used to be good but deduct 5k from your salary since they now have a 5k deductible before you get any benefit from their health plan.  

You will be given little or no opportunity to progress your career as promotions as they are issued out as a popularity contest.  If you do a great job, work late hours, but don't interface with outside teams you won't even get a chance of being considered for promotion.  Leave the company and come back a few years later and they may hire you at a better title, that's really the only way.

You will be required to work overtime as everyone at Qualcomm is.  Qualcomm only allows their time tracking to show 40 hours a week (I can only imagine for liability purposes) so even if you work your butt off you won't be able to prove it.  Qualcomm hires a lot of people coming from other countries and works them to death.  When employees finally figure that out, they leave which is why Qualcomm has such a large turnover.  

Not a great experience at all.

headline: Nepotism! Dirty politics! Stay away!!!
pros:
Some awesome engineers around. If they don't see you as a threat, you will get to learn a thing or two.
Decent perks.
cons:
Rampant nepotism.

Managers hiring 'loyal' people from their previous orgs, their boss's/peer's wives, and they all live in a happily ever after, where they scratch each other's backs.

If the San Diego overlords are happy(or you can make it look like you are doing good), you can get away with anything. Even if the entire team report who reports to you, complaints to upper management, they will not do anything because, end of day its all about business.

There is no thing as ethics, decent behavior or even decent language. You will be punished for not being complacent, threatened for asking questions.

Have personally witnessed  employees tortures and pushed into depression because they could not get along with the middle management.

headline: For women : not the best
pros:
Amazing benefits - no premiums for healthcare
In my department, my coworkers were among the smartest I've worked with. Everyone at this company is high performing and competitive.
cons:
After I left Qualcomm, I received a payout from a lawsuit alleging gender discrimination in the company. From my experience there, this was not surprising at all. I was the only female in my department and often felt over looked - I could describe many situations where this was the case but for brevity I won't. Additionally, this is not the place for working moms. Long hours are expected and I can name coworkers  who were passed over on promotions because they were pregnant/ just had become pregnant/ etc. 
maybe this will change going forward - I hope so - but only time will tell.

HR department is useless and helpless, so there is no hope. 
Not a good place for young engineers.

headline: Did Qualcomm grow too big too fast?
pros:
- Good work/life balance is definitely achievable, at least where I was.
- Working with great people who care about a quality product.
- Moved from matrix style managers to direct report managers. 
- Lots of interesting problems to solve.
cons:
- Work culture has taken a big hit recently with various layoffs and lawsuits
- Has grown into somewhat of a monolithic software company that moves slowly internally.  Also, a lot of the internal tools and processes are outdated or unrefined.
- The communication and collaboration between different teams is abysmal. 
- Benefits package getting worse every year.

headline: Young Engineers Go Elsewhere (run don't walk);  Older Q worker's try to retool and find another place that is growing.
pros:

cons:
-"has been" tech company (best years were mid 1990s to 2015), i.e. young engineers go elsewhere
- very top heavy in titles
- rolling layoffs w/ staggered exit dates so as not to trigger WARN act.
- CFO running the ship in 2017.
- no vision; still stuck in the past of 1) new products need patent licensing model and 2) how to move a bit from here to there quicker.
- merging w/ NXP soon which has been a bigger headcount, i.e. more layoffs.
 - everything in R&D a couple of degree separation from mainline of business.

headline: Family Company Turned Sweatshop.
pros:
You get to sample a little bit of everything as a design/analysis engineer. The technologies that Qualcomm is involved in are cool and you get an opportunity to see where the electronics industry is headed in the future. I would say there's a lot of flexibility and job training, depending on what team you're on. There are really smart people at this company...for now. If you're in it for U.S. citizenship it seems that their immigration support is great, but you will work for it. 

The pay is okay compared to most companies.
cons:
The CEO is absolute GARBAGE and so are most of the SVP's. They don't know what they're doing with this company. The culture is dead, benefits are going downhill, engineers are no longer motivated to work, and top talent is leaving. Not to mention the CEO did nothing when immigration was threatened and he paid himself $60.7M during the year of layoffs. The previous CEO cared about his workers, this current one does not. 

The cultural downturn is a drag on your work ethic because everyone is moping around. Teams are now hoarding information in fear of being let go. They're acquiring companies left and right and the jobs are moving overseas. I honestly would say unless you're in it for the H1B and U.S. citizenship, run far FAR away if you have another offer in hand. 

Projects get cancelled before they're completed, even if QC is trying to enter a viable market. I think the company is however large enough that it will survive. They're not opening reqs, so if 10 people from your team leave and there were 20 people to begin with, you're stuck with the work of those 10 people.  Apparently when Paul and Erwin Jacobs were running the company it was more family oriented and the employees were valued.

If Intel catches up to QC's modem technology or they lose the Apple lawsuit, the company is dead. That's sort of a scary thing considering how they're investing billions into it as well. The constant threat of layoffs and lack of perks that other tech companies provide will add way too much stress to your life that it's best just not to care much about your work, which means your career won't grow as best as it should.

cons: Goals shift fairly often. My job description never really changed. I was always tasked with more or less the same things, so my responsibilities were always the same, but what we were working toward changed fairly frequently. I can't blame them, though. They had very little money and were being pushed and pulled. Startups ...

headline: Not worth it
pros: Opportunity to travel around the world. Used to be able to fly business class. Working with smart and driven people
cons: The culture is absolutely terrible. Within my team, turnover was more than 50% last year. People dropped like flies. Why? Because management only cares about meeting its numbers. They do not care if they kill their staff in the process of doing so, by making them work insane hours and jump through hoops just to meet expectations. As long as they hit their goals and look good in front of their managers, they're happy. Management will lie to you about promotion potential from day 1 (interviews). They will keep dangling the potential to be promoted in front of you, just to get you to work harder for them. In the end, you (along with many others who were promised the same thing) will be sorely disappointed. I joined the company thinking it would be great, that it was the best place to work in San Diego, but trust me, it's not worth the pain, sweat, and tears to have the "Qualcomm" name on your resume.

headline: Senior Manager
pros: I worked on a small team that thrived under good management - we were encouraged to find new solutions, given reasonable goals, and for the most part I felt valued as a team member. Great pay, great health benefits (until 2016), and flexible work schedule due to long hours (meaning I could work from home after hours). Sadly, my team and I were affected by the 2015 layoff.
cons: Favoritism is rampant in upper management, they will move their friends into departments for "process improvement" with little or no experience. It's typically disastrous to the team as they try to please the new management while making improvements that are not helpful. It's a lose-lose deal. Everyone is also over-worked and therefore unwilling to adopt any new process that costs their team any time or effort, even it the long term gain outweighs the short-term learning curve. Promotions are difficult if you are not playing the political game.

headline: Challenging times likely to continue in 2017

headline: Stable company

headline: Good company
