Cutting edge technology
Competitive field with a lot of potential for growth
cons: Large company, mobility within the company isn't as good as it used to be.  Roles are more specialized, which means you're either just doing managing, or just doing development, there are few roles that enable you to get experience in both areas.

headline: Horrible management, no work/life balance, a lot of unhappiness. Avoid like the plague!
pros: Onsite gym, San Diego weather, onsite training courses assuming you have the time to attend.
cons:
Countless! Management is terrible in this company. The place is heavily political and hostile. The environment inside the company is dog-eat-dog. For each person who gets a "good" performance review, an equal number of people must receive a "bad" performance review no matter how well they have done since people performance has to follow a bell curve distribution. This leads to cutthroat internal competition. Backstabbing within the team is encouraged and rewarded. My manager asked me blatantly to spy on my coworkers, find mistakes in their work, and write those things in reports behind my coworkers back since I am popular and respected among my peers. When I refused to do so, he threatened me that he will lower my performance and I will miss a promotion. I tried to look for another group to switch to within the company but failed. Switching groups via IOS is extremely difficult and almost impossible without the help of your manager, so if things aren’t so good between both of you then forget it, you better find job at a different company. 

HR folks are useless and liars, don’t ever think of going to them with a complaint. They will almost always give you the wrong advice and will contact your manager behind your back and tell him that you came to them with a complaint even if they promised it will be confidential. HR department is just there to protect the company from any possible lawsuits; they don’t give a damn about employees. HR is a useless department completely.  

If you don't want to get chewed up and spit out - and that can happen at any time - don't work there. The pay, which is below average, and benefits aren't worth the stress; it can make you physically ill. If you want to be a “good” performer by their standards, you are constantly stressing about being visible, not upsetting the wrong people and trying to stay ahead of your peers by any means, and if you have ethics, generally you don't do well. I know people who have done some truly unbelievable things to get ahead. If you aren’t cool enough then you will be singled out and targeted even by people you don’t work directly with. Be careful; don’t let yourself to be an escape goat for their failure.  People advance in this company by backstabbing and connection with corrupt middle/upper management. You have to be your manager’s favorite pet to get a promotion. A bad manager can really prevent your career growth no matter how well you performed or what other people think of you.

The performance review process at Qualcomm is entirely flawed and completely subjective. Managers have the right to veto and override all 3rd-party feedbacks on an employee. They use this to create phony PIPs to eliminate anyone who dares to question their practices. 

They hire a lot of fresh college grads with PhDs to do menial bench test work and treat them like indentured servants because most of them are foreigners and they need visa sponsorship to stay in the country. Qualcomm likes to hire PhDs straight out of college to make sure that they don’t have previous work experience so they don’t know that the workplace could be better elsewhere, and work them 24/7 in a killing environment. What they say in the interview is completely different from what the actual job is, a lot of sugar coating. The work is boring, repetitive, requires basic programming skills or not at all, copying and pasting. Basically the positions are low level engineering job that a technician with an associate degree can perform, however the internal policy requires that the job is filled with recent grads holding advanced degree. Utilizing your knowledge is frowned upon because that threatens your lead/manager’s image and makes him look weak. Most likely your work will be stolen by your lead.  Managers are unappreciative, insulting and downright rude. If you have a PhD don’t waste your hard gained education or time here.
 
Foreign nationals in the company from India and China alone constitute more than 90% of the work force (diversity?!!). Those foreigners gang together, speak their own language in meeting rooms, labs, and hallways, and, shamelessly, hire and give promotions to their own kind. They hide work related information and keep the information within. They also gossip and share departments’ internal matters with their buddies in India and China. That creates a hostile environment for people who aren’t racially/ethnically related to the group members or not from the same region/village.

 Mid-level and upper-level management are insecure and totally useless and clueless, they are there just to collect status from the engineers who do the actual work. Those managers create a lot of useless meetings, wasting the engineers’ precious time, while spending the majority of their day resting and vesting.

The list goes on and on. That caused a few people to commit suicide by jumping from the 11th floor balcony in San Diego campus. That just shows how horrible the environment is for foreigners to kill themselves in a company that claims to be one of the best 50 companies to work for in the world! If you are well educated, have morals and values then think twice before joining this unhealthy environment. 

Working at Qualcomm feels like living in a third world country on an American soil.

headline: Not for engineers, only for HRs
pros: No pros that I can think of.
cons:
1. More of an HR company. There are so many HRs that I keep wondering what their job is
2. Facilities are poor. I work in a building infested with flies, mosquitoes, lizards and many others
3. Only some of the employees work. The rest are to send the status report to their bosses
4. Even the experienced people have no proper technical knowledge. 
5. Those who have been in this company for a long time, they are not at all flexible and think that their way of working is right and all others are not.
6. Racist place. All the people who come from a certain place group together and they don't like others
7.  Career stagnation. After sometime, you don't know how you can keep working on the same thing for the rest of your career
8. Pathetic culture. You are expected to give new ideas out of nowhere, just after joining. If you don't, managers are not impressed.
9. You have to literally steal other's work for you to progress

headline: Senior Staff Engineer/Manager
pros: Good compensation by San Diego standards, technically interesting and challenging work in most groups, facilities and benefits are quite good, though benefits have reduced somewhat in recent years.
cons: Work hours can be crazy, many groups in QCT are poorly managed, highly political environment and beyond a certain level there's no growth at all unless you are close to a VP or somebody higher up who can get you the right visible roles.  Future in many groups seem uncertain in the US since there is an consistent effort to move jobs to lower cost regions such as India to improve profit margins.

headline: Terrible company
pros: It's all relative. If you compare jobless to working at Q then of course it's better to have a job. So the pro is at least you have a job. If you don't want a long term career, don't want to be properly rewarded for your time and effort, don't want a interesting job, then it is good for you.
cons: Too many. First of, they have many of their people leave good feedback here to cover up their terrible biz practices. So I would go to other websites and/or get hold of real people working at Q for more accurate info. Overall, don't expect a long term career since the good spots are already occupied by chinese and indian people who are horrible at mid to sir management. Dont expect to get rewarded properly for your time(a LOT of your time) and effort, and when it's time to let people go you are most likely the first since they protect the people in their small circles. They also hire many H1B to replace Americans and/or old people. It's still a bargain to hire young fresh H1B at even the American workers' price since they work extremely long hours so company get huge investment return out of them at the same price, and American workers simply wont work 60+ hours weekly regardless of pay. The reason why H1B work extremely long hours because Q threatens to not petition for H1B their green card unless they work extremely long hours so Q can get much greater investment return, and therefore there is no reason why they want to hire American workers even at the same price. So Green Card IS the ultimate leverage Q has against H1B and highly qualified American tech workers who can't find jobs taken by H1B.

headline: Mixed bag
pros:
The company has historically been on a meteoric rise, riding the wave of smartphones. It is a highly engineering-centric company (like all tech companies) with fundamentally good products.

You get to live in San Diego, and the stock options (if they give them) are actually worth something.
cons: If you are marketer, run away. The company places no value on marketing, and assumes that every engineering intern is just as qualified as career marketers to make marketing decision.

headline: Software Engineering Intern
pros:
-Amazing intern events that include surfing lessons, hackathons, Servapalooza, summer on the lawn(QSOL) events, technical talks, laser tagging, carnivals, soccer tournaments, volleyball tournaments, movie nights, and much more
-the Campus Team is great and makes the internship really fun
-You get to work on ground-breaking projects that will change the future of mobile technology
-My team treated me as a valuable member of the team
-Got to push code on a weekly basis and my features were being used by other members of my team
-Get housed in a fully furnished, luxury apartment with maid service
-Live in sunny San Diego where there are tons of things to do during the weekends with your fellow interns
cons: - Like most tech companies, there is a lack of diversity. For example, the team that I was in did not have one female developer. However, recently, Qualcomm has made efforts to change this by holding conferences for diverse college candidates

headline: Poor management. No employee appreciation.

headline: The company has lost it
pros: You can work at some of the most interesting technologies. I have personally worked on cell phone SoCs, Automotive SoCs and Virtual Reality SoCs. It is very difficult to get these kind of exposure in other companies. Also company intranet is treasure trove of information. It is always easy to find an expert on any particular technology sitting inside the company.
cons:
a)Extremely political. Higher level promotions are rarely based on merit but more on favor from one VP to another.
b) Compensation is not all competitive with the market anymore.
c) Qualcomm's most important USP was that it was employee friendly. Recent actions have completely tarnished this image. Irwin Jacobs will be sad to see what the company has come to.

headline: Slowdown on innovation front
pros: Smart people (upto a certain job level), OK compensation/benefits, but they are not keeping up with industry lately.
cons: No risk taking in middle upper management level, Upper management keeps trying to please customer, middle management keeps trying to please upper management. Hardly any new innovation being here. QC has started buying other companies doing something new, rather than trying it for themselves.

headline: Worst company you can work for!
pros: Salary is the only pro here, nothing else is good about this company. Please avoid this company if you want some work life balance.
cons:
No sense of work life balance.
Forced to work for extra hours without recognition.
Extremely poor management, first and second level managers have no managerial skills at all.
Boot licking culture is prevalent.
No recognition or appreciation for an employee even though that employee is working beyond his capacity. 
No regard for health or personal issues of employee.
If you give an honest negative feedback for anybody, this will not remain anonymous and will come back and and bite you. Why take feedback if nobody wants to improve.
Work practices are too slow and inter team dependency will further slowdown your work progress, but this will be counted as a negative point for you no matter what.
If you ask for a particular kind of work/team, a straight 'no' is the answer from management.

headline: Negative work life balance. Expect weekends and overnight calls.
pros:
- You will gain ATE tester experience.
- Great city to live in.
- Professional employees.
cons:
- Product Test Engineering department is like a 24/7 grinder. Unless they grind you 24/7, Qualcomm will not be able to keep up with the demand for consumer chips which are in high demand.

- You will only gain ATE tester experience. You will get cornered into ATE and your career will not have other possibilities and you will get stuck in production manufacturing environments. 
Even though Qualcomm makes cutting edge technology, as a product test engineer your knowledge will be constrained and you will gain no knowledge of design, architecture etc.

- Great city to live in. But you will not have time to enjoy it. We got calls during weekends and also got calls around 3-4AM to resolve tester issues so that production will not stall. Qualcomm took no measures to arrange a night shift and if you don't answer the call, it will be noted in the system and you will get chopped eventually. 

- Professional employees. 90% of them are under the age of 30 and are Indian. It will be easier if you are Indian too.

headline: Nice place to work
pros: As hardware companies go, Qualcomm is a good place to work.  First, a lot of FTEs get their own office.  It is so good for productivity and lack of interruption to be able to shut my door and not hear other people's conversations.  This alone is a reason to work at Qualcomm as versus another hardware company, or even one of these nouveau open-concept software companies.
cons: It's a major corporation and can be crufty.  I hear the pay is not as good as other places, but honestly I feel like I'm paid enough.

headline: Not awful
pros: The work is potentially interesting. They have some decent people. Free lunches are pretty good. The office environment is decent. Big rewards for the lucky ones.
cons: Way too focussed on the US office. Working across sites is not well managed despite pretty resources. The US guys don't tend to get in until late and don't understand that it's unsociable to keep taking meetings late in to the evening. You need to be on the right projects to get the big rewards.

headline: Senior Staff Engineer

headline: Good company that started to lose its way in the last few years
pros: Good benefits, competitive pay, certain perks that may be attractive to some (swimming pool, modern gyms, special events and fairs). Generally good-natured people at the lower levels. Work that can occasionally be very satisfying in the end product, with a product and technology that is arguably fundamental to modern society.
cons:
Merciless workload, which is not a problem by itself, but in many roles, that hard work resulted in limited intellectual pay-off and recognition. In the 1-2 years leading up to when I left, the company was in a constant state of cost-cutting which meant a lack of people for the work to be done. This of course led to constant stress and long hours in an endless cycle of tape-outs, sampling dates, and process changes. In more than a few former colleagues, all this stress directly impacted health. 

For most roles, the overall company culture values quantity of work and expertise in a narrow set of skills vs. a diversity of experience and employee development, which makes it extremely difficult to move within the company. Applied to dozens of internal opportunities during my last 6 months when I wanted to try something new, but got only one interview. I consequently started to doubt my own abilities as an engineer until I was hired by an arguably more-prestigious employer, which made me realize maybe it was the Qualcomm (especially QCT/QTI) culture and not me.

headline: Planning is problem
pros: good salary, benefits, HR policies, flexible timings, working from home, good for ladies, very good projects, innovation, you will be encouraged to do patents
cons:
Need to support on weekends thru out the year
Surprisingly sometimes few managers will ask you to stay on weekends and ask you to brush, take bath, and sleep in the office. They say breakfast, lunch and dinner will be provided.
Though facility is there to order food if you stay late few managers don't like to approve your order.
Again surprising thing is, few managers who have late night meetings they will go out to eat and come back to work, so eventually in that team you will finally stop ordering food even if you stay late because of work.
No manager asks you to stay late in the office, and at the same time you have to meet your deadline. If you miss your deadline couple of times that's it, you can search a job outside, no need to talk to them.
Few managers expect you to be superman, I mean even if you are new to that domain/project/team, from the day 1 they will expect from you an expert results even in design/architecture.
They over commit the dates to customers and force employees to meet the deadline.
They don't increase head count and don't give you time to learn and do the things.
In skip level meeting if you say anything, that's it you are done. Hope you may be scolded or you will have a discussion with your manager to understand that your understanding is wrong.
If you want to move another team, it's your dream will never come true. If you are so lucky you will get moved so easily.

headline: Transitioning
pros: Qualcomm was built and flourished based on respect for each and every employee, granting individual autonomy and removing barriers when encountered, and promoting a work hard, play hard culture.  These simple corporate cultural traits enabled advancements in wireless technology to flourish.
cons: Qualcomm leadership has lost its way; they are disjointed and not aligned.  WHat was once and engineering driven company is now run by finance and legal opportunists - where once ingenuity and thoughtful risk was encouraged and rewarded, today predictability and short term results (at any costs to employee sacrifice) is rewarded.  Employees are paranoid and waiting for their ax to drop, resulting in no loyalty and lost synergy across the enterprise.

headline: Feedback
pros:
Used to be stable
Used to have good benefits
Still the drone bees help each other a lot in every day task
cons:
Boring after many years of service
Some VPS are very technical. Even they survive only by "unnecessary" politics.
No interest in mentoring employees.
Mostly, dive and learn to swim by yourself attitude.

Favoritism is a norm 
Favoritism changes depending whats in for them
Promotions are based on time in title, not the maturity
Major differences in pay scale for similarly performing members.
Company heavily defends questions on policies
HR almost not open to hear suggestions
VPs take the bulk of the profit and all the salary.

High quality colleagues and senior management. Very technical people in engineering team. Beautiful headquarter campus.

headline: Earn at cost of your personal life. Worst Experience
pros:
1)Brand name
2)Good Compensation & stock options
3)Sometimes tasks are interesting
cons:
1)No space for personal life. You might need to work 12-15 hours a day on average. If you forget your personal life, you can survive. I didn't use the word work-life balance because there is no life at all.
2)Expectations are more, since your peers are living to work, you also have to live to work.
3)No training for tasks. You have to dive and swim. Cannot expect proper guidance to everyone.
4)Change in location/teams is very tedious. The teams are not assigned based on skillset.
5)Policies are favoring the company not the employees. HRs use the word, "as per the policy", whenever you are raising any concerns. Your concerns are often turned down. 
6)You have adjust to team timing. Even when you are leaving at 5pm in the evening, you might need to mail "Leaving Early Today"

Tension in the air as people await news of layoffs and group politics can be extreme. Hard to move to other opportunities within the company, and can only make lateral moves.

headline: Design and Verification of Modules in Soc Device. Used UVM Systemverilog in verification methodology.
pros: Very knowledgeable management for charting direction of the various divisions and departments in t he company.  The company seems to value their employees a lot.
cons: Usual large company downside in that they are very much beholden to the shareholders and so have to cut staff on large numbers if necessary.

headline: Things are not getting any better
pros: San Diego, location location location
cons: Long working hours. Outsourcing to offshore teams. Poor compensation while management still gets paid overly well.

headline: Things have gone so wrong at Qualcommthat you have almost no chance to thrive through skills, hard work, and dedication.
pros:
Still the wireless industry leader. 
Has enough cash to invest or waste.
Competitive total compensation in San Diego although benefits have been cut down significantly recently. (Compensation per unit hour is bad).
cons:
Favoritism has become the norm starting from hiring to assigning project tasks, and of course to promotions. 
Technical skills and knowledge has little value now. If you are technically sound and hard working/executing, but without the skills of buttering your bosses up, you won't reap any rewards these days. 
Introducing bugs and fixing them elevates visibility and is much more rewarding than doing quality work with no bugs at all. Complete U-turn from the original naming of "Qualcomm" as it derived from "Quality Communications".
Upper management is surrounded by cronies and they cronies sell mostly their own interests to them. They present others works as their own achievement. So, the engineers who are doing the actual job are rewarded very little or nothing compared to how much hard work and sacrifice they make. 
The upper management is out of touch from recent technologies and not motivated either. This is killing innovation and ingenuity here. Their and cronies narrow views have become the views of the company overlooking any other options/ides.
There are too many VPs and senior directors who do not contribute, but draws huge salary and benefits at the cost of salary/benefits to young and mid-level engineers. Career advancement is almost saturated.
Engineers are over worked days, nights, and weekends while the benefits go to others. Considering the long hours and weekend works, the compensation is not good at all.

headline: Corporate Accounting
pros: Good benefits. Stock and Retirement Savings.
cons: Executive management has decided to outsource all finance functions.  Extremely political environment.  Company no longer values its employees.

headline: A 'Thank You' message
pros: Besides being fair, Qualcomm is a company works hard on the comfort and encouragement of its employees. I feel lucky to be part of its team.
cons: The only negative point I can think of is the small annual wage increase which I thought would be bigger. But all in all it is still better than many other companies.

headline: Engineer

headline: Qualcomm
pros: Stable, competitive, culture is okay
cons: head heavy, people come in and never leave!

headline: QCT
pros: Most co-workers are friendly. Very flexible schedules. Performance review process is simpler than most places I've worked and lets you give your input. Lots of on-the-job training for RF engineering. Much does depend on which department you are in also. I'm basing on my department and the ones I interacted with.
cons: Lots of tribalism and territorialism. You will be taught, but not too much if it threatens someone's turf. High percentage of H1B worker and American citizens seem to be in a small minority. Rational is still given that it's because of a shortage of engineers in the USA, yet they have multiple layoffs.

headline: Bureaucracy, politics and chaos
pros: They pay you a salary
cons:
Support services are in chaos, IS have had experienced staff and managers fired, you deal with someone with a script in a call centre somewhere on the other side of the world who is polite but clueless. Calls are then lost and must be chased daily for weeks before anything happens.
Director to President level managers all act like they are petrified of being fired and are much more worried about covering their rears and looking good than about actually solving any problems. Bucks get passed instead of issues being worked on, it's like being in a giant game of pass the parcel with the prize inside being a ticking bomb.
Promotions are rationed and handed out to favourites rather than on the basis of ability.
Everybody is terrified of making commitments in case they can't meet them, so rather than make a decision people call a meeting and try to delegate or escalate until they are off the hook.
San Diego is the centre of the universe, but don't have a clue about time zones and expect UK to work on their schedule then act all hurt if we don't want to routinely turn up to meetings scheduled at midnight.
Management keep saying "no more headcount reductions" rapidly followed by another round of sackings. Do they think we are too stupid to notice?
I worked at CSR for over a decade before it was taken over by Qualcomm, it's impressive how fast they have turned around the company and made it into a disfunctional nightmare.

headline: All about the Benjamins...
pros: If you get the right boss, your experience can be pleasant. Unfortunately, in my experience, there are very few good managers at QCOM. And the executives are all heartless, greedy individuals who only care about how many zeros are in their bonuses, while they put a pay freeze and eliminate bonuses for the people who actually are "lucky" enough to not be laid off...
cons: Bad management, so-so benefits that get worse each year as they keep taking more and more away from the employees, too few of people to do the work therefore there is absolutely zero work-life balance. Irwin Jacobs established a company that put people first and money second. Since the Jacobs are no longer running the company, the company treats there people HORRIBLY! In my group, we have 1/3 of the employees as we did 5 years ago and twice as much work. You do the math --- Massive amount of work + a third of a workforce = 80-90 hour work weeks... with no overtime, no bonus, no raise. I wonder why the attrition rate is through the roof, and no one wants to come to the company, so positions stay open for 15 months?????

Layoffs in the 2015.
Cut bonuses and stocks extensively. 
In general an old-fashion company who hasn't caught up with time when providing for employees. Personally, I think having offices of every employee is a waste of real-estate and prohibits collaboration.

headline: Company in decline
pros: Still better than many companies that one could work for - in a good industry, lots of smart people, fewer opportunities than before but still affords opportunities for people
cons: Although Qualcomm is still probably better than many companies, it is far from what it used to be.  The company seems to have lost its way in how it treats and supports its employee base.  It used to provide a competitive pay and benefits package and had many leaders who were not only smart, but also just good people who put the needs of the team and company over their own self-interests.  The pay and benefits packages are no longer competitive and the culture of the organization has definitely changed and not for the better as new leaders have been brought in or promoted. This isn't a reflection of the HR organization but rather a reflection of the entire executive management team.

headline: Testing Engineer
pros: Free coffee. Free working meal. Free breakfast on every Friday. Good location for commute. Collaboration working culture that move projects forward easily.
cons: Fast paced. Most people are not friendly and not respective. A compete and self-center culture, just like most other company culture in the bay area. No training at the beginning of new employment.

headline: "They got fat, dumb and happy."
pros: The company is inside most smartphones in the world, so your work is far reaching. Company covers many technologies and products.
cons:
How the mighty have fallen. 

To quote Forbes - "Qualcomm’s head has been in the sand until recently about the nature of the situation,” Rasgon says. “Steve and the entire management delayed the recognition of structural shifts in the market. They got fat, dumb and happy.” 

Rampant nepotism. The founder gave his son the keys to the company and that established the culture. Now every VP gets their children internships and jobs whether or not they are qualified or attending college.

headline: Not what it used to be
pros: Free drinks in the break room.  Catered lunch meetings.  Free on site gym.
cons: Confidence in the company has eroded as the smartphone market reached maturity.  Canceled raises and bonuses in the spring.  No guarantees fall will bring anything.  As expected, attrition is the result, as good engineers are leaving, and the mediocre ones are staying.

headline: The Trust Is Gone
pros: Access to latest technology, at my level, work with some really great people, still making a decent salary.
cons: Since the hostile takeover of Jana Partners, the focus of management has been on cost reduction, which can otherwise be read as value reduction.  This is a race to the bottom.  The best and brightest who can afford to leave, are.  Qualcomm was in the Fortune top 20 companies to work for a few years ago.  Now they're not in the top 100.  I have to ask myself why?

headline: Director
pros: Good salary and one of the best companies in San Diego (not a lot of other options if you live in SD).
cons: Not the awesome company it used to be. It used to be an innovative company with top talent, however, with morale declining, continuous layout offs/restructuring, little or no career path and growth and mid level management, people are looking elsewhere. It's become an old, stale company.   Merit has decrease - bonuses are basically non-existent even for top performers.  Healthcare is expensive - huge difference when we went from amazing healthcare to horrible overnight. Too many drastic changes hit all at once rather than easing through the these transitions.

headline: Stay away from CE Group
pros:
While it might be overall a good company to work for , do stay away from the CE group

1)  You can really learn a lot technically , if you are in the right team. 
2) Benefits were good up until 2015
3) Campus was good
4) San Diego is amazing
cons:
1. For the CE group, basically there is no learning at all.
2. Expect No work life balance. And i mean No work life balance. You are going to be put on round robin basis, to do weekend support , even on long weekends and holidays. So expect to be on weekend support every 2 or 3 rd week depending on your team size.
3. Your team leads/managers  don't know how to talk properly . Expect to be yelled at frequently.
4. Full of politics, multiple layers of middle management.

headline: American males need not appy
pros: Great if you are from Asia and have total disregard for American employment laws called EOE that Americans hold dearly
cons:
Good luck if you are an American. This company loves H1B's and asians
Merit increases statistically are ethnicity/gender and ethnicity/gender of your boss.   
E.g.
Female with Female boss:        25% merit increase & director promotion path especially if incompetent
Chinese with Chinese boss:      20% merit increase & promotion
Indian with Chinese boss:         2% merit & no promotion
Indian with Indian boss:           25% merit increase & promotion
Chinese with American boss:   Same as everyone else - there's a EOE law that American's are obliged by
Indian with American boss:     Same as everyone else - there's a EOE law that American's are obliged by
Other:                                          Good luck- take the package

headline: Company in decline, still much potential to turn around
pros:
* Plenty of great talent and sharp engineers
* Latest and greatest technologies to work on
* Decent compensation package (declining)
* No significant alternatives in San Diego
cons:
* Executive management doesn't seem to get the gravity of the situation or is doing a very poor job communicating to employees. For example, why are all they always trumping up great results and roadmap, but our stock is down 50% and financial results continue to reduce every quarter.
* Seems like the company is run by bean-counters instead of engineers. Intead of focus on innovation and R&D, meaningless cost-cutting measures reduce employees morale
* Salaries frozen for more than a year, no bonuses, health benefits reduced
* Many sharp folks are leaving the company, the rest and thinking about it

- High rates of attrition in Bay Area resulting from low salaries given high life expenses, they lost people not only to competition but also to companies in other software industries.

4) HR dept doesn't seem to be active at work. (I got relieving letter, after 1 month of leaving company causing lot of trouble in my new company)

headline: Review comments
pros: Very competitive work environment, many excellent engineers , interesting and various products with many customers across the wide world. Very good salary & benefits.
cons: business increasing in India and closing down / reducing caps sites in Europe and US. Making lots of roles redundant and laying of people.

headline: Stuck in Old Ways
pros: You get to live in San Diego while working for tech, but otherwise, not much else going for it these days
cons:
Outdated technology (e.g. Office 2013).

No choice in laptops (must be HP/ThinkPad) and even new hires are given recycled laptops.

Benefits aren't great anymore. Health benefits are still paid for, but if you need to do any sort of medical procedure, be ready to pay out of pocket until you hit the deductible.

No sense of brand ambassador. Management makes complaints about a certain company's phone line cutting into our profits, yet an entire row of employees is using that company's phones.

Talent pool is dry, people don't want to work at/for Qualcomm, so all the new hires are essentially leftovers from other hiring pools.

Work/life balance is a myth here, does not exist. Manager is constantly complaining about staying at work until 9-10pm as if they're hinting they want us to stay with them.

Middle management doesn't know how to manage, all about shmoozing to get that next promotion.

headline: Ex-software engineer
pros: The ability to move between teams. Some divisions are very comfortable to work with and most managers are sensitive to your complaints and eager to help you do better. Working with smart professionals is always exciting.
cons: Job growth is not very great as compared to telecomm of similar sizes. Strenuous work cycles. Of late became too process heavy and less agile.

headline: Enron Of Technology

Unadulterated greed of the executives
Managers who hoard money, bonuses, travel, and visibility
No attempt to grow employees, equivalent to a technology sweatshop
Office Politics

headline: Good Company

headline: Screwing over employees
pros:
Smart people in some teams working on very interesting projects.

Decent compensation and benefits but going away very fast.

Flexible work schedule in some teams.
cons:
Massive cost cutting while returning billions of dollars to investors.

Reduction in medical benefits.

Bonuses and stock awards for employees have been cut.

Executives are compensated based on how much cash they return to investors in the form of dividends and share buyback programs. 

Employees are fleeing the company because the management doesn't seem to care about the employees.

Big company feel. IT often gets in the way instead of solving problems. No laptop upgrades unless it's broken and can't be fixed. 

Being at the bottom of the technology food chain sucks. We are fighting for scraps thrown at us by ecosystem players. We need to move up the food chain.

headline: Design verification manager
pros: The pros is a work place if you want to live in San Diego, as other companies has been moving offices out of town.
cons:
This company has a dis-functional HR. HR invests in writing ethic policies but without enforcement of those. They'll periodically send you forms requiring you to electronically sign that you must comply, so they are covered.
Employees are leaving the company at a much higher pace now as the stock in lower. The reason is dis-trust in the company's values and such deployment of those. Previously they stayed for the money, and they are voting now against the company with their legs. Employees resignation rate is significantly higher than the market average rate.
Management further exhaust those who stayed behind with even worse unrealistic milestones and pressure to fulfill those. Very low volume of opportunities to move in the company.

headline: Not a great place for women
pros:
Big company benefits - good HR structure, opportunity to build skill and organize rest of your life around work
Smart people to work with - accomplished, modest and of great attitude.
It can be a great place to work if you are with the right manager and in the right team
Growth largely depends on the team and your role. It can be great if you are in the right place at the right time.
cons:
The percentage of women in development teams is terrible - only about 3 in every 100. This leads to several issues of gender bias, mostly unconscious.
The system is very hierarchical - management doesn't like engineers to disagree with them and any sense of disagreement can get a lot of negative attention
Performance review process is not very transparent - the manager has quiet a lot of power in it, even though the evaluation matrix includes other teams. 
Processes are not very well defined - this creates a lot of inefficiency and overhead to engineering project that the management doesn't account for in their schedules and timelines to achieve milestones

headline: Qualcomm A Great Place to Work
pros: Qualcomm has great flexibility.  In general the benefits (including fringe benefits like 401K match, having a gym, etc.) are great and the people are wonderful to work with.  As with all big companies, depends totally on the team you are in, but in general Qualcomm has a very enjoyable work environment.  As long as you are productive and get your work done, they let you decide how to go about doing it.
cons: It suffers from many of the challenges that other large companies suffer from.  Achieving a balance between consistent processes and flexibility.  In addition it faces some major business challenges in the near future.

headline: Horribly Political and Disruptive
pros:
- Some great minds still work there
- Reasonably good benefits (used to be much better, however)
- Used to be an absolutely awesome company. Is it possible for that to happen again?
cons:
- A top-heavy company, resulting in a horribly political environment with much backstabbing as all levels of management try to "make their mark" without regard for the inefficiencies resulting from most of their initiatives.
- A tough company for females!
- A Culture of Fear: an environment where high level executives decide it is OK to yell at everyone in every single meeting instead of leading by example and identifying the real problems that are occurring within Qualcomm. Note to Bosses: If you are yelling at everyone, feeling that your whole team is lacking, maybe you are the problem, not your team. Turn inward, work with your team in a positive manner, and fix the issues!

headline: senior engineer
pros: Good work and life balance. Lots of projects to work on

headline: Staff Engineer - Software
pros: Qualcomm used to be one of the most exciting company to work for.  The company was very generous to provide various benefits directly and indirectly.   We were working hard, countless long days, but we were very happy and we were taken care of when the reviews came.
cons: Looks like Qualcomm hasn't come up with the 2nd biggest idea to bring success to the company.  CDMA was the cash cow and it has been the only cash cow.  As technology moving forward to 4G, 5G, the company is only be more difficult to be the king of its domain.  Worse that the company has been growing. Now it is a huge company, so more people are sharing the smaller and smaller cake.

headline: Management cuts costs and loses the Cream
pros:
- HQ is located in a good City.
- Modem R&D Technology hub
- 401k matching is the only benefit left.
- Best Medical Plan (gone from 2016)
- Competitive Cell Phone Market

Observation: Glassdoor has listed conflicting pros and cons for Qualcomm:
 pros 'good work life balance' and con 'bad work life balance'.

 It could be due to fake reviews from Qualcomm officials who are desperate to cover up. Speak to an actual employee working at Qualcomm before accepting an offer. Also each team is different.
cons:
- Steve, Paul and entire Management team has poor vision. They don't know they are not up to mark. They cannot visualize the future of technology. They are OUT of ideas and so now they have resorted to copying.
- As the company looses market, they are cutting costs everywhere and punishing employees.
- Due to a Poor Brand Image and lack of vision the products in a few years are going to suck more.
- The cream (best of the best engineer/other staff) are gone/leaving. What is left is un-qualified people who are highly political.
- Racism is high and each team is polarized with people from the same race.
- Beware if you are an engineer/senior/staff : Managers will use you and dump you after they get promoted.
- Poor Work Life Balance and Un-ethical colleagues.
- No bonus/RSU and promotions for 2016.
- Software Engineers can learn nothing at Qualcomm. 
- Work Quality Standards are lowering each day: Jobs are moving to China/India.

headline: Contract Development
pros: Great people, everyone geared up to move things forward, non-technical people very technical by outside standards. Exciting technology.
cons: Things get hard when deadlines are tight, but that is the nature of the industry. Sometimes hard to get co-ordination across different areas working on similar issues (ok, very difficult), especially if you are a contractor.

Highly political work environment, no more raises, lack of job stability (management said no layoffs in our small team but one week later, one of our teammates is gone), work/life balance is pretty bad for hardworking, competent workers but great for career inhouse politicians who like to "work from home."

headline: Going Downhill Fast
pros: You may still find pockets of good teams who can still provide some good experience and learning opportunities.

Qualcomm underestimated the number of engineers leaving for other tech companies and the bureaucrat senior level directors who survived are simply followers versus leaders. Right now, its not an attractive place for new, young technically savvy employees who would rather find a company that has a strong future vision.

Too many relatives of senior management are hired with little to no experience

headline: Falling from grace
pros: Historically good compensation and benefits (although this is changing)
cons:
1) Lack of diversity at the top (i.e. no women in leadership positions)
2) Long history of promoting from within has created an inbred culture of executives who cannot see the world from different perspectives. As a result, the company is slow to respond to industry changes.
3) Top-heavy organizations have too many thinkers (making the big bucks) and not enough do-ers (making much less, but carrying the majority of the workload)
4) Wastes money on the wrong things (i.e. huge corporate branding campaigns instead of meaningful product marketing)

headline: Qualcomm - Not The Company It Use To Be
pros:
+ Industry leader
+ Opportunity to work with leading-edge technology
+ Challenging work environment
+ Diverse workforce
+ Fairly compensated for the amount of work that is expected of you
cons:
- Low employee morale due to recent layoffs and cost-cutting moves.
- Company laid off ~15% of employees in 2015.  Focus seemed to be on getting rid of the "expensive" employees who had been loyal, committed employees for 8 years or longer.
- Cost cutting moves have taken away many of the things that made Qualcomm a great place to work.  Gone are the superb health benefits, lunches & Friday morning bagels, beverages in all conference rooms, celebrations/parties for tapeouts, annual holiday parties, etc.
- No work/life balance.  Expectation in many groups that work will continue from home in the evenings and on weekends.
- Questionable hiring/promotion practices that are based upon a person's ethnicity and whether it aligns with senior leadership.

cons: Difficult to strike a good work/life balance (and management constantly encroaches on it), limited growth and advancement opportunities given Qualcomm's current corporate outlook. and a fair amount of inter-office politics at the executive level can make it hard to certain things done.

headline: not a good place to work
pros: i dont see anything that you wont find elsewhere. only pro i can think of is you have a job and you are getting paid regularly
cons: not sure about other teams but for us, no innovation, no scope to learn anything. doesnt add any value to your resume. no proper channel to assign work (work doesnt get assigned by your lead. anyone with an equal or higher title can walk up to your desk and dump work on you and your lead will be totally in the dark). about  more than 95% of the work is unnecessary and can be automated. matrix management system is the worst way to review an engineer. the manager drafting your performance review has no interaction with you on a daily basis. a week before the review, you will be asked to summarize everything you worked on during the last review period. this causes many people to spend 10% of their time working and 90% of their time projecting their work and making sure  everyone THINKS he/she works too hard. the perfect recipe for disaster

headline: Fat,old company trying to lose weight and find itself
pros: The best part right now is the people.  It's great working with smart, like-minded, and hard working individuals coming together to get projects done.  I have been working with pretty much the same people for over 6 years.
cons: The worst part right now is the people.  Company leadership seems lost. Very little guidance or direction for the future of the company. Very unsure of where the company is headed.  Department management is poor which causes chaos and unhappy employees. After recent layoffs, it's definitely a very different company!  No pay raises and change in medical adds to the tough times now.

headline: Had a great time earlier, now disappointing
pros:

cons:
- Managers and HRs have very less respect for employees. You are taken for granted.
- Office politics is a pain. If you are in a wrong team/department where your supervisor does not like you, you will have a very hard time.
- Work-life balance is hard. You are expected to work overtime for the most part.

headline: Got a bit complacent

headline: Good place to work but not the great place it once was
pros: Large network, great people, flexible hours, variety of projects/technologies, pay is decent and the benefits are still good though not what they once were.
cons:
Benefits are changing.  Recently went from two performance-based raises/bonuses per year to one per year (starting in 2016).  Also, due to Fall 2015 layoffs employee moral is down.  

Over the past few years we've seen most of our "fun money" cut from the budget.  Rare but boring offsite team builders, no company sponsored happy hours, no company sponsored lunches, and no large company holiday parties.  Flashback to 5 years ago when we had Dave Matthews play our company-wide 25th anniversary party...those were the days!

headline: Strategic Realignment Shakeups!
pros: The biggest benefit Qualcomm has given me is its San Diego location.  Other than that, good points are that it's a large employer, has good benefits, and offers a competitive salary and stock programs.
cons: Corporate "strategic realignment" has meant lots of lost jobs.  It's a shame, given Qualcomm's history of being a stable employer.  The environment has drastically changed in the 8+ years that I have been a Qualcomm employee: from warm and fuzzy to cold and corporate.  It's truly tragic knowing that so many are losing their jobs to overseas/nearshore folks when Qualcomm has billions in the bank, but MBAs are steering the ship these days.

headline: No Longer the Best

Many employees are very unhappy and want to leave.

4. Employees are expected to work late nights. So, there are long working hours and over pressure.

headline: Overall good company going through some rough times
pros: Overall treats employees well, but this is at a corporate level.
cons:
Some departments are run very poorly, and executive management either doesn't notice or doesn't care.  How much you enjoy working at Qualcomm will depend on your chain of management, some people have good managers, some have very poor managers.  Unfortunately, there are a quite a number of poor managers who tend to promote people like them, resulting in more poor managers, but this is a common corporate problem that is not unique to Qualcomm.

The company is going through some rough times at the moment and is trying to modify their business as the mobile phone market matures.  This has resulted in reduced profits, which in turn has resulted in decreased bonuses and stock awards.  This action is completely understandable, and I do not fault them for having to do this.  Unfortunately, for certain employees whose overall compensation is heavily based on receiving stock, this has resulted in a compensation level that is no longer competitive with the market.  Hopefully the company will get back on track and have an improved financial outlook sooner rather than later.

headline: Losing Culture & Values

headline: Bad management, poor/non-existent future prospects
pros:
Depending on the group work life balance can be overly good.
If interested in wireless communications lots of classes, trainings
cons:
Very poor management that put the company in a tailspin towards bankruptcy

Engineers are paid much less than the Silicon Valley competition, execs paid more.

H1B program is being abused both to shackle immigrant employees and to depress wages.

Eagerness to work and being a solid contributor is taken for granted immediately. Promotion, pay raises based solely on number of years with the company not on performance, which drove out a lot of the brightest engineers.

Total compensation package is in a constant deterioration since the past few years.

Constant risk of being laid off with no potential reward to make up for the risk is something you have to accept

Overall I would suggest accepting a position at Qualcomm only as a last resort if nothing else is an option, this is especially true for software engineers.

headline: Great experience overall
pros: Qualcomm employs and encourages some of the brightest minds and hard working and hard playing employees in the country, possibly in the world. Benefits were the best you could get (though that's changing) and there are numerous perks. The culture values employee development, innovation, and engagement and the experience and on the job training gained is first rate, possibly unparalleled.
cons: Management and culture is overrun, almost crippled, by nuanced political rules and games.  Bureaucracy and legal and security fearmongering slow product and business development, by months, if not years. Critical opportunities have been missed and millions wasted. There is a brand awareness and competitive value proposition problem that must be put to bed and continuously cultivated.

headline: Outlook not so good
pros: Good company culture, main campus in San Diego is really nice, free soda and other small perks.
cons:
Too political and difficult to get anything done. Most of the work in IT is CYA and new ideas and projects that don't come from "architects" are rarely listened and backed by management or just blatantly stolen with no credit given.

IT is extremely siloed and pennywise-but-a-pound foolish with budget, spending extraordinary amounts of money on vendor IT software solutions and licenses that 90% of the industry uses for free but balking at small cost incurrences.

Anxiety over job security is high with the recent restructuring due to activist investor influence and shrinking of mobile market revenue.

Promotions in IT are done on a "she was next in line" political process instead of review feedback.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Decent Benefits, easy to gain experience even if you don't have any (careful this is also a con).
cons: Everything gets lost in translation.  Too many layers of management that don't have a clue about the technology below surface level.  Low talent gets put into high talent required positions because management doesn't know what makes a good engineer.  You can tell it's been a cycle of promoting unqualified people for over a decade.  As a software engineer in a hardware heavyweight industry, I recommend you stay away.  If you want a good software company to grow in, make sure you pick a team which understands what it takes to build good quality scalable extensible software.

headline: Politics and resistance to change
pros: The salary is good and the company is in San Diego.
cons:
It's a company of little fiefdoms, where people in different fiefdoms are seen as the enemy, and usually you are expected to not cooperate with them. The communication culture is horrible; not only do people not respond to emails within a day or two, they often don't respond at all, or will only respond if you cc a director or VP. Very little gets done without it being escalated to a director or VP, and even requests for people to just do their jobs are included in that. The politics are petty and destructive, but it's difficult to survive and impossible to advance without participating in the politics. 

While these cons have been around for a while, as the stock price drops, these cons get worse and the atmosphere gets gloomier and gloomier. Hopefully the past couple of days will help.

headline: Work at Qualcomm

3) Room for innovation. Management always tries to inspire the employees to innovate and provides them with necessary resources.

Management helps out each other and are in a group of their own, and low level engineers in their own group.

headline: Make Qualcomm Great Again
pros: One of my favorite things about working at Qualcomm is that employees at any level can perform meaningful work and turn great ideas into incredible success stories.  There are a lot of smart, talented, and energetic employees here who care a lot about the work they do.
cons: While employees have shown their passion for the work they do and their commitment to Qualcomm, it has really started to feel like unreciprocated love.  Management has become very bottom-line driven, in many instances penny-smart, pound foolish, and it has sent a terrible message to employees that they are not valued.  When I moved across the company to join Qualcomm, it was a company advertised as one of Fortune's top 100 companies, and I was awe stricken by the fact they paid 100% of healthcare costs for employees and their families.  Neither of those things are true anymore, and the negative changes have piled up in the last 12-18 months (cuts to benefits, bonuses, stock, headcount reductions, reputation).

headline: Good but could be better
author_position: IT Staff Systems and Security Engineer
pros: Qualcomm has a great and diverse culture that makes it easy to work with and collaborate well with others.  There are numerous avenues for training opportunities as well.  Here we are able to work with cutting edge technology and ideas as well as given some leniency with thinking outside the box for solutions.
cons: With the recent layoffs and belt-tightening going around, the benefits have been reduced, along with the workforce.  As one person said the other day, the "golden handcuffs" have come off.  Advancement opportunities for mid-level people are stale to non-existent.

headline: Top execs continue to be over paid
pros: The salary and all the benefits that came with it were great. The people that I worked with were fantastic. Severance was very generous.

headline: Once a superb technology oriented company now losing direction
pros: Latest wireless silicon, powerful apps processors, bright coworkers and fast paced environment. Very good  infrastructure and facilities such as library, gyms, cafeteria etc.
cons:
Too much politics. Too many high titled folks earn their pay by sending emails day in day out. Don't know what they do and are very  poor technically. People making noise are dear to management. Some senior directors take care of their leads even if they are dumb a**es. I frankly don't understand the role of so called project engineers and project managers. In some money losing groups these folks outnumber engineers!
These folks are technically so poor, they don't have a future outside this company. But they are sitting here and drawing fat paychecks. Rampant favoritism in hiring and intra company transfers. I heard stories from some guys who moved from India that their buddies who had moved earlier and by now become managers, made it all too easy for them to be transferred to San Diego. Too many loud people roaming the hallways and thinking they are truly great.

headline: Qualcomm at a Crossroads
pros: Good salary and benefits, though benefits are dwindling in last couple of years and look to further decline.  Many, many great people there. When experienced people are hired they are finally looking more to the outside, bringing in perspectives other than the “Qualcomm way”.  Very flexible work hours, most people get along very well, intra-team.
cons: Easily the most mismanaged company on so many levels I have ever worked for, or are familiar with.  The practice of promoting from within, while honorable in intent is often disastrous in practice when it appears to have been based either on time-in-service or quasi-nepotism.  So many people have been placed in positions of leadership with no hint of either management or leadership skills, it is damaging to both the environment tactically and the company strategically.

headline: Sorry I worked there ...
pros:
- Healthcare benefits used to be decent
- I have never seen a qualcomm employee commit a crime in my presence.
- an overall score of 2.6 rounds up to 3 stars
cons:
- Don't come here if you're a software engineer.  You will be treated as a cog in a machine.
- Disturbing lip service to a certain set of fashionable corporate values.
- Very corrupt behavior in the markets it enters.
- Management is unstable and tends to pursue goals half-heartedly, then cheap-out, I've seen it happen a dozen times.  The 810 chipset fiasco is the latest in a long series of examples.
- Annoying history of advising management to go in a certain direction, almost getting fired for "saying something crazy", then whole company was forced in that strategic direction 3 months later by the good sense of outside competitors, it happened many times, my career was almost destroyed each time, especially after I was proven right.

I worked there for a total of 12 years, and the only way for an american to get promoted is to leave the company and then return in a different department.  It's astonishing that they can pay a senior engineer $130k but managers start at $180k, the company is top-heavy with slick, overpaid managers who contribute very little to the bottom line.  In my experience, you can get a great review when there is no money for bonuses and no stock available, but when there is something valuable on the table, it always seems to go to "friends" of management, and I mean that not in a good way ...

headline: Mostly good, but lots of changes recently
pros:
The work environment in Raleigh is quite positive and collaborative.  This team started out small, so while we're under the corporate umbrella, the culture here is different than San Diego.  Sure, there are some politics, but those seem to occur mostly when dealing with corporate in San Diego.  

Qualcomm has always tried to compete with the big players when it comes to hiring, so benefits have been more in line with the Googles and Apples of the world than they have been the industry average.  Lots of small perks (free drinks, yearly picnic, etc) and the biggie--free insurance, even for the family.  These are quickly eroding, however. 

We get to do cutting edge engineering work without having to live in a city with a huge cost of living, and we make products we are really proud of.
cons:
Local perception is that Jana partners came in and wants to squeeze us for all we're worth then get out.  Layoffs didn't hit Raleigh too hard (yet) but some of our work was transferred to other sites, so rather than having a tight knit local team, we're spread across time zones.  That was the environment in my previous company and I don't prefer it.  The small perks are going away little by little--many of us watched this happen at previous companies and we know that once cost cutting starts it usually never stops.  Hopefully that won't happen here, but most of us assume it will.  Insurance is still free but starting next year pays out virtually nothing until you hit a (middle range) deductible.  

Overtime is generally expected.  I sometimes get "vacation notices" for people who will be out of town for the weekend.  A lot of people here are in the habit of working at least a little every day, and many of them work an excessive number of hours.  Hard to say if it's expected by management or just a self-imposed drive to keep up with everyone else, but it's way more normal here than at my last company.

Adding a little bit to address my "culture" rating below.  I gave it low marks because the culture of the company as a whole is "California".  Everything is CA-centric, and there is little effort put into making the "satellite" sites integrate into the corporate whole.  My previous company did a much better job of being a group of sites with similar culture throughout.  Qualcomm is CA all the way, and CA values are often at the extreme of the values of the rest of the country (example, we hear about saving water constantly, when it's really only an issue in CA right now).  The culture in Raleigh is mostly task oriented.  We get along, we work together.  We help each other out.  It could be better but for the most part it's very good.

headline: Great technology company, being driven to the ground
pros: Strong technology, talent, scope and scale. History of strong innovation and culture, team structure to make that possible.
cons: Very short sighted management and product decisions. Middle Management not supportive of new ideas and focused on near term goals at cost of scalable solutions.

headline: Great company, what happens next?
pros: Well-run company, very profitable, employees are consistently highly competent.  Even senior management is very technical.  Politics are not over-the-top, considering this is a big company.
cons: The work keeps moving through the night and weekend -- do you want to be "part of the solution?"  Decisions are ostensibly by consensus until that bogs down and a boss lays his foot down and decides, kind of weird process.  Decisions get made on the west coast.  Company is trying to compete with Asia as their patent moat erodes.

headline: Great company which can open other doors
pros: Total compensation is very good and the actual job can be interesting and challenging in good ways.
cons: The company has had lots of recent changes causing the job security to be less than it used to be

headline: Staff Database Administrator
pros: Fast moving, interesting work.  Lots of leading-edge technology in the database realm.  Great resources, training, contracted vendor experts (dedicated support engineers).  Truly a world class IT organization.  Really excellent place to grow your skills. Good salary and benefits.  Really smart people and good managers at the lower end.  Treated me very, very well for 15 years until I got laid off and then they treaded me even better in the transition out.  No complaints.  Just sad to go.
cons:
Unfortunately as with all companies moving from the entrepreneurial phase to older, more established phase, some bureaucracy is creeping in.   Lot's of night and weekend work.  But then they were always very fair in terms of compensation and adjustments of work time and location.

Company is struggling in the marketplace right now.  Hence the RIF that I was caught up in.

Too many people doing middle management and tracking. You could just end up executing test cases with no real value addition to your skills.

headline: Still Striving to Innovate
pros: A leader in commercial telecommunications. Initially, Qualcomm really took care of its employees and gave them means to develop their skills. Qualcomm offered very competitive salary, health benefits, and on-the-job training.
cons:
In my opinion, Qualcomm is lagging in the innovation field. At the will of its investors, Qualcomm relies on making its majority revenue from selling its top-tier chips. Consequently, its hard to propose an R&D project that falls outside the scope of selling its integrated solutions without it being shot down.

Work-life balance is skewed towards work

Recent layoffs were handled poorly

headline: Good only for people with Electronics Background, not for CS

cons:
1) Culture has went bad over recent years and a lot of work overload is being faced by employees, work life balance completely lost. Also politics among teams has led to an adverse work distribution among employees.
2) Only testing and debugging work given to freshers, hardly any development work done, bad esp for people with CS background
3) Salary hikes are pretty bad compared to other companies in the same salary domain.
4) Collaborating with US guys is a big issue, you have to work and collaborate till late hours everyday, which leads to a very bad work-life balance and you just cant feel free even after coming home

cons: slowing growth has chipped away at the almost academic atmosphere to allow types more accustomed to creating a more competitive, aggressive business environment to thrive.

headline: Technology without vision
pros: Great technical expertise in the staff, driven to execute well. Large company allows everyone to be part of something that can change the world. The benefits and pay are close to the best in industry.
cons: Top management lacked foresight to position company better in a changing customer environment. While products are still profitable, margins are under pressure and cuts are the order of the day to keep the bottom line looking decent. As more cuts are made, the worse the company position becomes in applying the real changes that need to be made, causing more cuts to be necessary to stay profitable.

headline: Not as impressive as you would think

Salary and benefits are the highest in SD
Free 24/7 gym on SD campus
The industry is very interesting and exciting to work in
cons:
Culture can vary widely between department. I routinely hear coworkers talk about how the execs and board of directors are "evil". People are very catty behind each others backs. Many people think that the management is clueless and stupid.
Lots of cursing, which in my personal opinion is very unprofessional. 
Pay isn't enough to live in San Diego. Its an expensive place.
Company is bloated, which is why there is downsizing occurring.

headline: Sr Hardware Engineer
pros:
- Competitive pay for SD area
- Lots of great people
- Lots to learn technically and smart people to learn from
- Interesting products to work on
- Flexible hours
- Fitness facilities in almost every building
- Great city to live and work in
cons:
- Non-optimal management structure (too many cooks in the kitchen)
- Going through cost reduction, so lots of penny pinching
- Engineering teams being outsourced, or under threat of outsourcing to India
- Bell curved performance reviews
- Promotion quotas to limit number of promotions per review cycle (in some teams)
- Arbitrary "minimum-time-served" promotion prerequisites regardless of whether employees deserve it or not (in some teams)
- Executive management taking vast sums of money as bonuses and skimping on bonuses for the little guys
- Very large company, so you get buried in corporate culture and bureaucracy at times
- Career advancement has a ceiling in a lot of teams due to top heavy nature of this company
- Recurring layoff rounds lately

Reduced benefit is a real bummer. Health insurance is getting a huge downgrade in 2016.

Company is really cheap. why does procuring a new monitor need to go to VP of finance? why is it almost impossible to get a laptop upgrade when your current one clearly no longer functions well enough for the job? Compared to companies in Silicon valley where employees are pampered Qualcomm really doesn't give a damn about the people doing the work.

Company politics is a joke, incompetent people at management level with their equally incompetent lackeys getting all the promotions and raises while the good people are hardly recognized.

headline: Staff Engineer
pros:
Opportunity to work on new technology.
I had several good supervisors.
cons:
There were a lot of managers who were technically smart, but not good at managing people or projects. There were a few managers who displayed amazing immaturity. I could not believe they were in positions of authority.

Qualcomm executive management seemed to have "magical thinking" about the company's ability to overcome technical challenges and make things work. Sometimes having smart employees is not enough. They spent vast sums on my projects over 5 years, but everything wound up in the trash can.

The "Internal Opportunity System" (aka IOS...the system to apply to different jobs within Qualcomm) is broken.

headline: Still the king of Mobile semiconductor business
pros: I joined Qualcomm in 2005 after graduating with Masters degree. It was the best company I could ask for employment. The engineers in our group and the groups we interacted with are super smart. I learned a lot during the first few years. Some Pros are 1) Big company where you can get lot of opportunities to move around 2) New grads can learn a lot from smart employee base. 3) Lot of talks/seminars for employees to grow their knowledge.
cons: Management should have been a little more proactive in looking for new opportunities outside mobile space. They are starting to do it now with drones and IoT. But they were in an enviable position a few years ago where they could have had a significant first mover advantage. But knowing the talent pool there, I believe they will be able to find new opportunities in the next 2 to 3 years.

headline: qcom was ok but is going down now

headline: Used to be a great company to work for
pros: Qualcomm has had a good working environment with lots of smart people. Good compensation, flex time, generous benefits. If thinking about working here talk to someone at Qualcomm who survives the layoff and ask them what they think.
cons: Given the current layoff situation, motivation is low, the original innovative culture is lost. Employees sitting and waiting for more layoffs to happen.

headline: Staff Engineer
pros: Leading edge company with good pay and benefits.  The work is both rewarding and challenging.  The company has grown very rapidly.  Free sodas and coffee.
cons: Schedules are very aggressive.  Promotions are very few and far between.  Offices are being replaced with cubicles.  The company has recently undergone a realignment and over 1400 people were affected.

headline: Software Engineer

- Industry leader
cons:

- Very high percentage of employees do not add value.
- Tough working conditions for some lab teams ( hundred of people cramped in a room )
- Low Base pay - if you intend to compete for the best talent you should be willing to pay the best.

headline: Great company to work for - until I was laid off

Positive workplace.  Technically challenging. Great benefits. 

Nice perks like free soft drinks.
cons: Challenging time at the company. Perks are being reduced - offices being replaced with cubes, reduced selection of drinks. Can be a high pressure workplace.

headline: Sr Staff Engineer
pros: Wireless Industry Leader with great technology leadership on mobile communication and computing. Abundant with challenging projects and smart engineers and business professionals.
cons: Recent Layoff may have impact on moral. As Q turns 30 years old, and is in lead position of maturing industry, keeping young talents would be a challenge.

headline: Good to work
pros: good place to work at.
cons: Nothing bad notice till now.

headline: Engineer Modem System Test
pros:
1. Good package specially for lead and above level. 
2. Yearly twice review cycles. 
3. Colleagues are helpful. 
4. Not many Intelligent people so no competition even average guy can be top performer.
5. Good stock plans.
cons:
1.  Qualcomm is not for intelligent people. Growth is purely based on experience not on performance. If you are a good performer might get 20% more stock or bonus but no career growth. 
2. No dedicated training sessions. Qualcomm conducts good Webinar and trainings but you have to make time to attend the training. Because of workload even though you are interested may not be able to attend the sessions. 
3. Too many unnecessary meetings. Most of the meetings are at US time . no conclusion on meetings. 
4. Too many bad decisions from upper management resulted in recent layoff. 
5. Quality of work is very bad in qualcomm hyderabad middle management is very pushy in nature. Don't know to handle things only thing they know is to put pressure on lower layer.
6. Partiality towards temp employees for any company events they are not invited. 
7. Very less travelling opportunities.

headline: Engineer
pros: High end technology and dedicated engineers.
cons: Communication gap in the Hierarchy.

headline: Senior Engineer
pros:
Good work-culture, flexible work hours, nice team members and great manager. 
No pressure of deadlines, very laid back environment in the team. No body cares about anything else as long as you finish your work with quality. Future looks bright.
cons: Going though a lot of budget cuts layoffs. Lot of non deserving people in the company, they could have been easily filtered out during the interview. Seems like interview process needs to be improved.

headline: A great chip design company
pros: One pro is that you cone to work any tine you like, and leave when u like. But be careful becaz it counts in layoff time.
cons: Since company's stocks are down, very low bonus, and more work becaz of layoffs, so negotiate a good starting salary and sign up bonus.

headline: Fundamentally a good company with talented, smart people
pros: Strong innovation culture led mostly by bright and talented individuals, Qualcomm is in a tough market with much more nimble competitors while being burdened with a bloated infrastructure and nonchalant attitude toward spending.  The Company rested on it's market dominance for too long, and their IP advantage is no longer substantial in a commodity market where product cost is paramount.  The restructuring effort underway will result in being better positioned to succeed, but the old inefficient habits die hard.  The leadership is taking bold steps to implement change but it could take longer than it should to complete and expenses are still very high.  Ultimately the company will be able to weather the shakeout of weaker competitors in the mobile phone business and expand into new markets but it really comes down to smart leadership.  This group is pretty good so the future is probably a good long-term bet.
cons: Slow consensus decision-making process hampers agility.  Some long-timers need to move on.  At times the behaviors don't match the rhetoric.  Executive micromanagement is too common.  Opportunities for career growth are rare but not impossible.

headline: Sinking ship
pros: Some team and/or people are very talented, diligent and self-motivated. Working with these people will make things much easier.
cons: Weak CEO and high management; Compensation is not competitive compared to other top tiers; Benefits are cut severely; RSUs will be much less than before and the share price is still crashing; Long hours and poor work-life balance; Too many politics; Office closure, layoffs and/or forced relocation; Company doesn't show respect to employees and many good people are leaving.

headline: Senior staff
pros: Best benefits, excellent culture, lots of design areas
cons: San Diego is costly place to settle in

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Work and leave everything personal on the company, they will take care of that.
cons: If you are workaholic than join the company.

headline: Used to be great, going downhill at alarming rate
pros: Had a scrappy, start up feel to it until a few years ago to the point that it was famous as one of the most nimble big companies around. Personally I had a great career at Qualcomm, starting as contractor and ending as Sr Staff/Mgr in 8 years. I consider myself fortunate to have joined while the start up vibe was still around.
cons: Sadly, in the past 2-3 years, the company began to rest on its laurels and shun all risks. It was as though the entire senior management collectively  went into "rest and vest" mode. Management kept talking about "Adjacent markets" to phone/tablet business without ever tracking it seriously. This despite the well known risks of depending on just two major customers for the bulk of its phone business. The results are now painfully obvious to see. Sadly, it is the rank and file engineers that are getting laid off and not the execs that blundered in the first place. The topping on the cake was labelling this the "Qualcomm way".

headline: Very bad work enviornment
pros: Not many anymore, many great people are leaving.
cons:
Benefits are going downhill.
Two major layoffs in last year
Mundane work and non transferrable skills
Bonuses are shrinking
Very poor work life balance

headline: Life at Qualcomm
