pros:
1) Opportunities to challenge yourself
2) Competitive salary
3) Fair rules on international business travel
cons:
1) Need improvement on diversity
2) Embrace open communication (not just talk about it but train leaders on how to do this right)

headline: They work to keep you happy
pros:
First off, this review applies to the Boulder office. Other offices may be different.

Good work/life balance
Competitive compensation
Work *can* be very interesting when working on cutting edge technology
Smart co-workers
cons:
Little insight into project health - it may be good one day, then cancelled the next.
Can be difficult working for a lead in a remote office.

headline: senior
pros: stable companystable companystable companystable companystable companystable companystable companystable company
cons: lots of limitation to work in the huge systemlots of limitation to work in the huge systemlots of limitation to work in the huge systemlots of limitation to work in the huge systemlots of limitation to work in the huge system

headline: Excellent company to work for!
pros: Great benefits, free drinks, flexible work schedule, and great people to work with!  Many internal resources to keep up with leading edge technologies and a large mix of different types of engineers and expertise.
cons: Difficult to climb up the corporate ladder...many intermediate levels...

headline: Good starting point for career in Silicon Valley
pros:
- Qualcomm has some cool hardware teams in Silicon Valley. 
- Can be a great place to pick up some embedded software or test engineering skills.
- Good work-life balance
- Free drinks/sodas
cons:
- Not as many opportunities as San Diego HQ
- Feels like projects in the Bay Area are treated as experimental, and HQ is fine cutting entire teams/divisions
- Takes a little too long to get promoted. Some employees deserve a promotion at least a year before it finally happens.
- Salary is noticeably less than similar companies nearby, but Qualcomm's health, bonuses, and RSU program outweigh most companies.

headline: it is ok ok...
pros: we get hikes every 6 month,
cons: you may stuck in the politics, sometime it is really hard to see your future perspective from manager. most of time you are just listener...

headline: Good place to work
pros: Good salary, challenging work, smart people, great benefits
cons: High workload, work-life balance could be better. Can be very political at times.

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
Work life balance
Employees and management are considerate and caring
Compensation and benefits are above-average
cons: Growth opportunities can be limited, though salary increases are consistent with the market

headline: Probably the best company I ever worked for.
pros: I think that the positive things about working for Qualcomm were the outstanding benefits package (free medical, dental and optical insurance), great pay, plenty of opportunity for advancement, excellent in house training and education benefits   The working environment was stimulating in that there were always new projects in the pipeline so that you never got bored working on the same thing constantly.
cons: The workload there was incredible and there never seemed to be enough time in the day or enough people to get it done although we all seemed to manage to get through it.

headline: Great benefits,  good market strategy , could use better leadership
pros: Excellent RSUs, bonus, health plan and vacation time. Average base salary. QCOM offers engineers the opportunity to work on a variety of technologies.
cons: Many old timers promoted to managerial positions lack planning /leadership skills.  Daily status meetings (mornings, evenings and weekends) makes work/life integration difficult. Too many processes negatively impact the execution of the projects in a very competitive market.

headline: Good pay & benefits..
pros: Compensation appraisal every 6 months, Healthcare benefits ,free food,RSU after every 6 months, bonus rewards etc.
cons: Too much company politics, lack of visibility of work & long work hours/ meetings sometimes on weekends too.

headline: No complaints
pros: Good salary, benefits, love the people
cons: work-life balance, no part time or flexible schedules

headline: Great Compay
pros: Qualcomm is a flexible and interesting company to work for.  Typically work is fun with opportunities for learning, travelling and taking on new challenges.
cons: Often open offices are used (benefit for some I guess) and depending on which location you are in opportunities for switching projects or advancement may be limited.

headline: Good Place to start your career
pros:
The review is respect to QCT
-Colleagues are friendly.
-Has reviews twice a year
-Management is not informed if you are trying to switching internally until you get an offer.
-Better Work/Life Balance
-Exposure to bring-up
cons:
-Not much challenging work
-Attitude of finger pointing to other teams while resolving borderline issues.
-Political in nature. Promotions are given more to favorites rather than on merit. This largely affected the morale of the team I was in and overseen the departure of great talent both internally and externally.
-Not enough ownership is handed to engineer.
-Lots of redundant teams doing the same work.

headline: Challenging yet satisfying
pros:
Very stable company. If some division gets closed for business reasons, employees are not fired but moved to different group within company
Good Bonus/ Perks/ Total_Compensation
Complete review twice a year - very few Tech Corporations have it
Quick on Immigration Processes - Best point for international professional
cons:
Plenty of Pressure. Work Life Balance in several team is pathetic 
Corporate Politics - expect it if you want to grow and foster
Too many emails - more than 500 in a day ( one can filter it out)

headline: Great Company, Good perks
pros:
Great Work culture
Great knowledge gain
cons:
Work Life Balance
Salary Could be better

headline: Exccelllent organization, challenging work, great co-workers and a good market position.
pros:
You will be working with some of the best people in the trade. Qualcomm has been carving a stronger and stronger market position for itself.  This makes the company comfortable in taking risks (nor all of which pay off) - hence innovations is highly prized (second only to execution) 

Compensation is good. The company adjusts to any changes in the external marketplace readily and quickly. This means that it shall not be the "most' you can get - but you will be very close - and hopefully the other intangibles will more than make up for any difference. 

People at Qualcomm are very helpful and collaborative. Team spirit is present everywhere. Generally speaking everyone is competent and many are arguably the best in the business.
cons:
With a few exceptions, Qualcomm does not make end products directly. It must read the minds of large cell phone makers, network providers etc.  There is always a difference that must be compensated when shipping the product. 

So, in several teams - especially which work on customer facing roles,  life shall be very busy - and even chaotic - with a lot of pressure. If there is factory that has stopped making phones - or a phone's launch is at stake - all because of a bug you are working on, the pressure (and visibility) can be intense.

headline: Good learning experience
pros: Ambitious and smart people, lots of oppor's to learn if you search for them. Fun options for meeting others outside work walls.
cons: Difficult to get past politicking, bureaucracy, and outside of dept silos if you are there to get work done. Lots of talented people get promoted to roles they can't handle, don't want, or are not qualified for.

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Tons of challenging engineering problems to solve.  Great work life balance.  Its in San Diego, which is a fantastic city to live in, weather, beaches, outdoors.  Compensation is merit based, so if you are performing well the bonuses and stock grants every 6 months will reflect that.
cons: Its hard to collaborate between teams.  Multiple painful and time consuming processes that are more optimized towards integrators and bug tracking then towards streamlined development and engineering.  The company is top middle heavy with too many directors and sr directors.

headline: Nice place to work with
pros: Nice package Flexible working hours
cons:
Support work
includes lot of travel

headline: Good place to work
pros: Great facilities, good management, and good benefits.
cons: Big company so little growth opportunity

headline: Amazing company!!
pros: Great work place, teams, benefits
cons: Company is getting bigger and lot of projects ongoing.

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Good place to work. Good number of opportunities within the company
cons: Too big of a company. A bit difficult to get out of the rut if you get in a poor division or group

headline: Low pay, lots of pressure, sweatshop like environment
pros: Location, facilities, stock going up, free pop
cons: Experience largely depends on the team. On my there were lots of pressure, overtime (even over night) is expected and implied. People are treated like slaves. Morale is very low, many members of the team H1Bs that have no choice but to shut up and work. Management does not seem to care about the work life balance of its employees.

headline: Excellent place to work
pros: Excellent benefits, leadership and career growth
cons: Work place can get boring at times

headline: Long Hours and good compensation
pros:
Good Learning curve
Good compensation and benefits
Smart people
Very process oriented
cons:
Loooonnggg hours
Internal competition for promition and bonuses can sometimes be way too cut throat and unfair

headline: Engineer
pros: work on the leading technologies
cons: Great company to work for

headline: Best Company to work for in terms of Employee Care
pros: Best HR policies , Serves Breakfast, Lunch in the cafeteria, Semi-annual review cycle, Transparent appraisal and review process, Open culture, Provides company stocks and cash bonus, lot of scope for self learning , best inter-team career opportunities within org
cons: High Workload, less communication within the teams / groups, prefers employees from southern part of india, partially less work-life balance

headline: Used to be great!
pros: Great campus, great food. Challenging environment.
cons: Qualcomm is a VERY large company and I can only speak for I.T. As with most large companies they tend to get management heavy. Management has to justify their position and in turn spend endless hours thinking of ways to tighten the noose. Things were much more creative and relaxed several years ago, now it is like kindergarten, constant reports, time cards, metrics and such. Raises have all but ceased and the great stock options are now a few RSU's.

headline: Great place
pros: One of the point I can add in Pros is "Pay Scale"
cons: Process is the Cons I can think of

headline: There is room for improvement
pros: Stable job, competitive compensation, good healthcare benefits, good 401k plan
cons: As a company, not creating enough growth opportunities for the future. Most employees work very long hours, there aren't enough facilities (late evening cafeteria, recreational facilities) at work place to ease the pressure

headline: Best Job ever
pros: flexible hours accomodate a disabled child at home
cons: Sometimes management feels it more important to be in control than to be right.

headline: Pretty decent company! Lot of technology and lots to learn.
pros:
- Exposure of cutting edge technology, Fast paced environment
- Lot of learning opportunities, Great for junior/mid-level engineers
- Very good health benefits, 401K, RSU etc.
cons:
- Sweat shop, lot of repetitive work
- Too much Process overhead
- Lot of management politics
- Not very transparent

headline: Great place to work for
pros:
Nice benefits, bonuses. The work processes is very clear and makes sense.
High quality engineers with good brains
cons: As any big business, they move slow and don't waive bureaucracy enough

headline: Strong company with limited opportunities for growth.
pros: Reasonable work hours and wages. Opportunities to work on interesting products. Rich history of leadership in certain technologies such as cellular, mobile phones, etc.
cons: Poor opportunities for progress in technical roles, no support for long term career planning, excessive levels of office politics and internal rivalry.

headline: Very average
pros:
- Benefits, which you may not be fully able to use if working 14+ hours a day
- Great health plan.
- QCT is totally manager/lead dependent. If manager/lead is reasonable, strong and powerful, you can go places. If not, you will go nowhere, even if you work hard.
- Exciting work.
cons:
- Some QCT teams have reversed pyramid structure. Number of Senior Staff Managers > Number of Staff Managers > Number of Senior Engineers > Number of Engineers. Hence lower levels in QCT, bear the brunt of work, because except for a few technically good mid level managers, most sit in meetings all day to increase their sphere of influence.

- People can steal work and claim it their own. Advertise your work to more folks than your lead.

- Some QCT managers, have no management skill. They  have the title to just increase their influence.

- Matrix structure for reviews. Find the most important senior player (manager, director etc) in the team and make him/her happy. Very political place.

- Do not waste any time contacting HR, they do not care. They are there to make sure that no lawsuit or issues for the company.

headline: The Best Place to Work in SD by Far
pros: Work/life balance, 100% paid benefits, on-site gyms, pay raises every 6 months, great people, encourage growth, and awesome end of year parties.
cons: Nothing.  Except if you work for QCT expect to work in high pressure / long hour environments.

headline: Management
pros: Offer internal online courses for employees to keep up w/programs, regulations and/or learn new programs.
cons: Acquisitions happen left and right which is great for the company but bad for current employees. New management often has no real experience and are put in management roles above those that should be managers. Unfortunately, this is how departments quickly go down hill and sometimes get eliminated.

headline: Every people are very intelligent and with passion for his work
pros: Qualcomm offers an very innovative workplace. also good employee benefits.
cons: Large company with very process. sometimes it's not so flexible.

headline: Pleasant to work.
pros:
1. work culture is good
2. Manager is always supportive
3. Easy accessible to higher managements: even VP!
cons:
1. Huge work load
2. Lack of Knowledge Sharing
3. No team activities

headline: Lively culture, broad palette of products makes work interesting
pros: Working at Qualcomm exposes you to hundreds of different products in several markets. Mobile is not the end of the story. Cultural and intellectual exchange are part of the job. On top of this, good salary and benefits contribute to satisfaction.
cons: The company is large and established, therefore career opportunities may be limited with respect to smaller companies. Communication across boundaries is sometimes difficult.

headline: Fun. Surrounded by intellectual people.
pros: Pay. As well as the benefits.
cons: Location, and social scene. It was okay.

headline: Great pay, but bad work life balance
pros: Chance to work on latest tech, good pay and perks
cons: Work life balance is not at all there, work culture is bad.

headline: senior software engineer
pros: Decent pay, good benefits and good job security policy.
cons: Work pressure can be very high sometimes. Frequent reorganizations.

headline: Place for workaholics
pros: The work never stops. There is always something rolling.
cons: If work is all that you care about then nothing like this.

headline: Awesome experience
pros: it is really awesome experience working in qualcomm
cons: No major cons very flex work hous

headline: Great culture but expect to work on weekends, regularly.
pros: Lots of perks, great culture, interesting projects.
cons: Long workings hours plus work on weekends. Regularly.

headline: Good company
pros: Great benefits, lots of resources for learning, friendly coworkers, flexible schedule. Your work impacts a lot of people.
cons: The workload is usually higher than what you can get done in 40 hours/week. There is some incompetence in some of the teams we work with, and corporatism does slow things down. Compensation is throttled by an open agreement between several large companies, including this one. Engineering is discouraged from pursuing management path.

headline: Stable, good salary
pros: Stable, good salary, individual office, good stock.
cons: Many people, tasks arevery segmented, it could be boring sometimes, lots of politics

headline: senior engineer
pros: more benifits. work balance. less stressful

headline: Synonymous with wireless
pros:
- Great environment for innovation
- Employee friendly
- Strong management team with focussed roadmap
- QC Changes strategy based on market very dynamically to stay competitive.
- Employee benefits, free health care insurance.
cons:
- Very conservative to hire more folks which is good in a way but also bad because folks are overloaded
- Salary is okay not very good.
- Brand name is virtually unknown to many unless you point out to them that their own phone runs QC chip at its heart.

headline: A good company to work for if you are in a good team
pros: Overall company is good. Good pay. Great benefits.
cons: If you are not in a good team, it is tough to work here. Sometimes the internal transfers are tough even though the company overall encourages it.

headline: Good company, lifer for a lot of people.
pros: Good benefits, opportunity to grow vertically.
cons: Horizontal growth minimal to non-existent.

headline: Staff Engineer
pros: Working on cutting edge solutions for wireless communications. There is no shortage of interesting current/future projects. Upper management genuinely wants employees to achieve a healthy work-life balance (though some project leads may not).
cons: Things aren't nearly as efficient as they could be (e.g. too many meetings). There is a wide range of managers - some are the best I have/ever will work with, others are blatant deadwood who take no responsibility for issues but claim all the credit for when things go well.

headline: Good working environment
pros:
Good interesting work. Freedom to switch projects, teams , departments based on your interest.
Very good benefits.
cons: Very busy and streesful at times.

headline: Good pay, no work life balance
pros: Good pay, bonus,shares,technology oriented. Free food.
cons: Work,work, and work yes you will get lot of work and you are totally occupied so much that you don't get any time for your personal life.

headline: Good Pay Benefits
pros: For an Engineer I was getting around 40K bonus each review cycle. Best part of working in Qualcomm is two review cycle each year. This keep you on track. Good timeoff.
cons: Relatively less smart people and more mass hiring.

headline: Great but work in Hyderabad is only bug fixing, which is bad

Free food
Awesome culture
Great work (most of it only in San Diego)
Really nice/helping set of people
cons:
Work in Hyderabad is mainly bug fixing
Work hours can  be too much depending on your team

headline: Fast paced, innovative company
pros: Love working here!  Leadership team is strong and very forward thinking.  The environment is constantly changing due to the rapid of technology evolving.  Pay is good, flexible work schedule, great health benefits.
cons: Not easy to get promoted here.  With the majority of the company being engineers, management has not fully bought into how marketing can help the business grow.  The technology vision is clear but how Qualcomm wants to position itself as a brand is not.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good benefits, salary bonus plus shares
cons: no challenges. Great place to work

headline: Used to be amazing but recently becoming too big with too many silos.
pros: The benefits and pay are great. The opportunities depend on your department but there is generally some opportunity to move around and try different projects.
cons: Lately, the silos and disagreement among management has made is hard to get your job done without getting into politics.

headline: Qualcomm
pros: Good Company.Decent Performance Highly competitive environment
cons: non existent feedback system and aloof HR dept.

pros:
good pay.
good care of employees
good food

work load
time pressure

flexible work hours , cutting edge technology . Good stock options
Qualcomm provides great development opportunities, people recognize hard work, salaries are good, One thing I like most is that team members are friendly and really helpful. They do not treat you as a competition while sharing knowledge.
 Really encourages personal development. There are lots of opportunities to participate in training sessions from interesting external folks

"filled with PHDs.. innovation focused environment"
cons: Be prepared to sacrifice all long weekends. sometimes demanding because of time constraints and deadlines

headline: Great benefits, good pay, good location
pros:
Company is an Industry leader
technical leadership and industry visibility opportunities
Very smart colleagues
Excellent benefits, fitness centres and classes, individual offices beyond certain grade
San Diego is great and laid back - lots of running trails in the vicinity
cons:
Engineering areas are over-staffed with lots of duplication
Mid-level management has poor management skills
Entrenched politics, cliques and mafias abound

headline: being aggressively restructured now
pros: You will be able to catch up with the world leading technologies in mobile industry if you get on well with guys at R&D and in marketing department.
cons: If you join customer engineering team, you will face difficulties with work and life balance and how to handle customers especially in Asia. They are very demanding. You will need to keep your skills outside of your office unless you are a developer because most of the time, you have to view questions and bug reports sent from customers to answer them as quickly as possible; otherwise you will get disappointed at your annual performance review.

headline: Good benefits
pros: Good benefits, good for new grads.
cons: salary is not very competitive.

headline: A pretty dominant company in an important industry, great city,

Good benefits
Decent pay for the location
Amazing weather in San Diego
Stable (for now)
cons:
Big company so a lot of overhead
Becoming more corporate
Moving from office structure to cubicle farms

headline: Great Development Opportunities Good Benefits
pros: Qualcomm provides great development opportunities, people recognize hard work, salaries are good, Onr thing I like most is that team members are friendly and really helpful. They do not treat you as a competition while sharing knowledge.
cons: Its too political. I have seen instances when directors call the project lead and ask them who is there in the LAB first before asking for project status. Be prepared to sacrifice all long weekends.

headline: Great workplace with understanding management
pros: Flexible work environment with excellent benefits
cons: Numerous teams and groups make it hard to have the right contact for projects.

headline: Staff Engineer/Manager
pros:
- Great pay, bonus, stocks, insurance, learning, 
- Great engineers to work with
- In the past had the startup aggression
- Flexible working hours
- Occasional 2-3 months of great work in a year
- The kind of schedule and culture Qualcomm has needs techie people with deep knowledge on their system, partly because lack of documentation.
- Excellent R&D in San Diego
- Great place for self-motivated people

Giving a good rating to this company because the pay is good. Otherwise it would be a 2 star company.
cons:
- Unresponsive HR
- India office is not an R&D as such - just a backend office of San Diego. Discarded and repetitive tasks are moved to India. Quality of work is bad in India. Mostly it is commercialization support.
- Top heavy, managers have become too distant from tech and lost touch with reality.
- Most Indian managers have given up on aggression and act as puppets of San Diego counterparts.
- Both HR & management have a great open door policy for management and tech improvements but nothing will ever come out of it.
- India office gives only lip service to innovation - an annual frenzy for one or two months, there is no real planning or long-term engagement to foster innovation.
- Too much posturing in India office. reality is - its just another Indian service company with better pay.
- No true leadership or growth planning, another management gimmick.

headline: Great place to work and meet highly innovative people
pros: Great team, leader in space
cons: sometimes demanding because of time constraints and deadlines. But rewards hardwork.

headline: Good company but too SD centric
pros: leader of industry, good benefits. You can meet excellent engineers and leaders here. If you are located in San Diego, then it will be great because it's center of Qualcomm.
cons: you can only part a small part, and organization is loosely coupled. There is no clear hierarchy, so you are easily lost in this big company. Sometimes it's not easy to get reasonable support as you don't know whom to come to.

headline: Just OK
pros: Great place to launch you career
cons: Pay not too great. Qualcomm tries to undercut your pay.

headline: I have been working here for 2 years, it has been excellent. Work quality is completely depends on team
pros: Most experienced people, good pay. So many learning opportunities
cons: very tight work hour, too many cost cutting strategies. there is no guarantee for work quality.

headline: good company,
pros: work hard, good stock bonus, good health insurance ( senior level)
cons: too many meeting, many higher level push to finish work asap( no reason), no work-home balance( weekend work & meeting).

headline: nice place to work
pros: good pay, good opportunity, good enviroment
cons: looking for more life work balance

headline: Good place to work for, the team is good
pros: Brand, the growing mobile market, the test work going on, Qualcomm stocks rising, the facilities, flexible timings, free lunch and coke, of course !!
cons: little knowledge employees, below standard employees, not having enough qualifications but boasting of the crappy work they have done all these years in Qualcomm

headline: so far so good
pros: Great benefits, work life balance, flexible hours
cons: Top heavy, too much fat.

headline: Very successful, growing company
pros: The benefits package is very generous and the company has excellent facilities.  The company is in a strong growth mode with long term plans for success.
cons: Difficult to advance your career.  Management tends to hire from the outside rather than promote from within the company.  Many people have been there a long time and have become complacent and ineffective in their roles.

headline: Very good
pros: Good place to work if you you work in wireless communication area
cons: Nothing significant except work-life balance is not that great

headline: Good place to work
pros: Amazing opportunities for learning, good management,
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: Very nice
pros: People are smart here and company are very suitable.
cons: no special cons for this company

headline: Excellent company to work for
pros: invests in training. management is very understanding and approachable, career growth is good and recognision is rewarding. will give qualstars for good work which is inspiring. good benefits like free medical insurance, prescription insurance,excellent gym, shuttles to and from coaster station to office, office environment is productive and cheerful. learnt a lot of stuff and new technology.overall very happy and satisfying to work. has flexible work options and work from home if needed.
cons: compensation and offshore team coordination

headline: Sample
pros: Technically challenging. Needs indepth systems knowledge.
cons: Work hours are long and strenuous.

headline: Really good management and great coworkers
pros: Everyone here is super nice. At least on my team, you can go to anyone with questions and they always have answers. Unlike many places where people work without degrees (eg Vons, gas stations, retail, etc) there is opportunity to move up  (even though it may be competitive), you can get actual raises (not just like 10 cents or something silly like that), and you will be recognized for the work you put in. Although you must start as a temp, if you last a year and your managers roll you over to regular status you will instantly enjoy 11 holidays and 2 weeks of vacation. Qualcomm also has an awesome healthcare plan and generous 401K match. Oh and free food and drinks! So good....And you are only expected to work 8 hours a day (not including lunch). The job is low stress and time goes by quickly. The engineers I support are also very nice.
cons: The area is super congested and it often takes me an hour to go 15 to 20 miles. It would probably be difficult to raise a family on this income alone. I don't know how high the raises are though for sure though.

headline: Great technology company with poorest of poor work life balance (no life only work)
pros: Great technology company and very stable.
cons: Work..work and work, nothing else in life while working here.

headline: Great benefits and interesting tech
pros: Q really encourages personal development. There are lots of opportunities to participate in training sessions from interesting external folks. There are also good tech talks from interesting external folks (e.g. CIO of GitHub recently gave a talk). Upper management is open to hearing feedback on how to improve things for engineers. It's a very engineer-centric organization. They're pretty lenient with working from home.
cons: It can be demanding if you don't know how to stick up for yourself. You have to know how to say "No, I'm going home".

headline: Nice play to work
pros: cutting edge of technology; filled with PHDs.. innovation focused environment
cons:
Heavy upper management; relationship with Sr. mgmt matters; Many Sr. Mgmt folks are individual contributors with poor leadership skills... 
Flawed performance review process. Who your manager is matters

headline: Best place to be in hard-core telecommunications
pros: Get to work on cutting edge technology.  Good environment that promotes innovation.  Management is employee friendly.
cons: Promotions are incredibly hard to come by in some departments.  Deadlines are only moved up not down.  Insane work hours.

headline: Good company only if you are in the right team
pros: Good company making proud products; good benefits; maybe the number 1 tech company in San Diego, a wonderful city.
cons: I fail to see a strong skill set in my coworkers.  People keep asking you very basic technical questions.  The promotion scheme is questionable.  Some people becomes managers just because they stay in this company long enough, and unfortunately they don't have good sense in technology itself.

headline: Innovative Company that executes with a good work/life balance
pros: Teams have flexibility to innovate while driving towards execution. Stays on top of the latest technology
cons: Work Life Balance in some groups becomes a challenge

headline: Growing Company with good compensation
pros: Competative pay; good beneifts; Multi-cultural work background.
cons: Organization has a lot of overlap and sometimes resulted in vague job scope. Expanding too fast unnecessarily and benefit has become worse.

headline: Good place to work, lot of work good benefits
pros: Qualcomm is a challenging environment and the workload is pretty high. The work environment is quite friendly and it's interesting working on the latest technologies. Benefits are pretty good so as salary and bonus.
cons: The company is pretty big so growing is a little slow. Workload might get very high and timelines might be very tight. And sometimes the bonus are not in line with the work hours

headline: Great place to work
pros: Bonus, raise, and stock twice per year. Very flexible management. Work/life balance.  Just get my job done and all is well. Many fun activities. Great coworkers.
cons: A bit demanding at times but what job isn't. While the rewards of 2x year reviews are nice the process is a bit of a burden.

headline: Qualcomm work life balance
pros: salary will be good and u will have better incentives
cons: difficult to maintain work life balance

headline: Flexible Work Culture with a good pay for a fresher
pros: Flexible work hours, rules etc. Industry best Pay (atleast in India). Pay hikes are relatively good.
cons: Hectice Work when Project approaches deadline and these scenarios are quite frequent once you cross your training period.

headline: Great work-life balance
pros: Have good flexibility in choosing the work quantity (of course will decide your growth rate), reasonable stock awards, but can be varying year over year. But the open door culture in the office encourages faster and better learning.
cons: Difficult to establish yourself if you don't push yourself, and the competition is pretty heavy. Difficult to straight forward feedback/comments from the management (have to ask explicitly for feedback). The salary gap is pretty large from one level to another, but I guess that creates a difference in the work experience. Other than that, I don't see anything specifically negative.

headline: Positive experience

cons:
This is specific to QCT engineering organization: 
Given the level of specialization required for many roles, its difficult to move from one team to another
If you have a good role, and are in a good team, you are in a very good spot. If not, its not as rosy, as its not very easy to change teams.

Also, base compensation lags other tech companies; Qualcomm makes up for it with the overall package, but the monetary compensation can be higher.

cons: It is becoming a big company and sometimes it is difficult to navigate the waters.  It takes a lot of effort to get a project off of the ground.  At times it becomes difficult to interact with people on a project as they are spread throughout the world - that is just the way it is these days.

headline: Great company for engineers, bad place for marketing or brand professionals
pros: Great employee benefits, good technology.
cons:
The company is a technology company that listens to its engineers but does not understand to listen to marketing or brand professionals it hires. When plans don't work they lay off entire divisions and the marketing folks are AWOL. I have many friends who lost jobs due to the company's treatment of marketing professionals, who they place no value on.  Qualcomm does not understand or value marketing, brand, sales - it's a technology company.
Many divisions are started by FOP (Friends of Paul (Jacobs) inexperienced senior management, who have no experience in marketing or branding, and come up with their own marketing ideas, fail to properly fund, follow through  or persist with the marketing or brand campaigns, don't listen to the marketing experts, and then fold the division when the sales don't work out.  Then they fire the marketing staff, start all over again with a new product and do the same mistakes:  complete lack of consumer insight.
They know technology, not consumers.

headline: Cutting edge technology in wireless communication

headline: Varies By Group
pros: Great benefits. Lots of opportunities for training on site. Keeps up with technology trends. I like the culture's values and events the company tries to push but not every group behaves like that.
cons:
Management requirements vary widely among managers. Some will allow working from home and will provide work loads that result in normal working hours. Others will push for a lot of on-site overtime. Qualcomm seems to have a lot of head count one year and little in another year which can make it difficult to transfer if you dislike your situation during a lean year.

Felt like there were too many people on projects for the scope of work. Made it difficult to own things and provide a meaningful contribution. The projects I was on seemed to move really slowly and my management often blamed the PM for this. We had PMs rotate on and off a lot and quit in this environment. Only one of them stayed with the company for more than a yea but this person found a way to transfer.

For some reason, rarely saw people promoted past staff level if they came in at a lower level such as senior. This was even among people there for more than 5-10 years. Many other companies you can work your way up higher in that timeframe.

Management is worst even to complain about any such incidents. There are many flaws in recruitment, people at same level are recruited at different level even the candidate had given 5 rounds of interview placed at lower level compared to candidate who given one telephonic. The moment employee starts questioning review gets affected and simple answer given by management is do not compare with others. You just cannot stay with this company looking at company name in industry.

headline: Learn and Grow or you will be miserable
pros: Amazing Work Culture and Great Career Opportunities at Qualcomm. For semiconductor industry, I would rate this as the best company to work for, especially if you are ASIC design/verification or hardware engineer. Awesome Benefits, pretty much cover everything. The Engineering talent we have is 2nd to none, but comes with a Caveat,  you will have to keep up with the best. Training and Classes of all sorts for learning, or just go and stand in any engineer's office (make an apt tho) and they will spend hours sharing their knowledge. Qualcomm has the best engineers who will help you learn and grow! People here love what they do, and usually if you even have like a 50% interest in what you are doing, you will really enjoy working at Qualcomm. Generous vacation policy and work policy is pretty flexible as long as you get the job done.
cons: First couple of years are the toughest and you should be ready to work crazy hours, but once you are up to speed, it gets easier and you can dictate your schedule.  Expectations will be high, but with all the help available, you should be fine. If you want to grow you will have to take the initiative as Qualcomm thrives on personal responsibility. If you do not drive your growth, you will not enjoy working here and will be miserable soon enough. Like with any big organization, there is cross-functional politics but usually engineers are spared from most of the carnage. Work hours can get quite out of whack because lot of work is done across sites around the world.  Lots of meetings.

pros:

-Pretty decent salary
-People are really smart

Didn't know what to expect going into Qualcomm right out of college but I couldn't have asked for a better first job experience. I had a lot of control on how I wanted to implement the tasks I was assigned (language, frameworks, etc) and also received a lot of help from my peers when I was stuck.

Work got a little too "comfortable" (which makes me feel crazy to write in the 'Cons' section) but I wanted to take advantage of my early 20s and experience the crazy rollercoaster world of startups.

headline: Great company going downhill fast
pros: Decent healthcare benefits, ESPP, 401K matching
cons: The company culture has declined drastically in the past 5 years. This is an extremely political place to work, and if you're in with the good old boys, then you're set; if not, get ready to see your career stagnate. Reviews are not based on merit but instead on one's manager's and VP's perceptions. Very few women in senior technical roles, and very basic benefits for parents.  Lactation rooms lack sinks and are adjacent to offices or meeting rooms. Instead of getting on board with equal maternity and paternity leave like most tech companies, the company provides the minimum mandated state leave and no more. HR is worthless; instead of addressing harassment and discrimination complaints, they state that they cannot protect the employee against retaliation (untrue in California). Multiple incidents of bullying, discrimination and harassment, even a couple of suicides, have not resulted in any attempts to improve the work environment. People are forced to come in when they are sick, work on weekends and nights, and work during vacation. Not to mention that compensation is not adjusted to market rates for employees who have been in the company for over 4 years. As a result, newer employees are paid 10-30% more than equally seasoned employees who have been loyal to the company for years. Hopefully Qualcomm can clean up its culture and get back to the great company it was - trimming the fat (and there's lots of it) will get the company back to its core values and allow it to innovate.

headline: Poisonous Entrenched IT Management
pros: Benefits, healthcare, vacation, flexible work hours depending on area of work, stock options (depending on your relationship with the manager), regular raises (also dependent on the manager and personal relationship).
cons: Management, good ol boys club, lack of professionalism, lots of managers, no leaders, lack of employee empowerment, system actively weeds out the most intelligent and forward thinking professionals, egregious wastes of money due to lack of basic knowledge in managing people or projects.  Personally witnessed millions wasted on tools and custom software that is never used.  All of these tools and projects were castrated due to personality conflicts or petty politics of who received credit or who was in control.  Although this is sometimes the reality in large organizations, QC is particularly unique in my what I have seen over the last 20 years.

About 4 weeks later I was told there was no work for me and I was given my notice - never saw it coming.  Severance was decent and part of the issue was being in a satellite office - but I could have had another position lined up instead of hitting the street.  It seemed they were cutting for cutting sake and not targeting less productive personnel.

headline: Qualcomm is a good company to work for. People here are smart and knowledgable

headline: Best Company in San Diego
pros: Great Benefits, Great People, Great Challenges - Innovation!

headline: Lots to offer
pros: Lots of flexibilty and resources at your reach. Qualcomm is demanding but it also provides many services for its employees and does the best it can to make sure you dont leave. Cafes, Gym's, Pools, basketball/volleyball/tennis courts.
cons: Many hours of work are expected. Work life balance is non-existent if you are in a higher positon. The work culture is to work days, nights and weekends. Employees will hit your car in the parking lot and dont bother leaving a note

headline: Great company, diverse opportunities
pros: Multiple groups, diverse opportunities, strong engineering culture with management coming from engineers instead of MBAs
cons: Hours depend on group, limited direct-to-consumer products, extra-specialization required to really contribute, large cohort of engineers 5+ years in the company so limited growth potential for new engineers

headline: Procurement, finding your place within a group of people can sometimes be a challenge.
pros: Their compensation and benefits are great.
cons: It is a great company to work for, but if you don't fit in or work with a bunch that are difficult to get a long with, then all the Pro's just won't seem all that important if you are miserable.

headline: Great
pros: The people and best benefits in industry
cons: none that come to mind

headline: Great work-life balance, though, probably not the best place if you are smart and ambitious
pros: Great work-life balance, stable company, great sense of contribution to the world
cons: Poor middle level management, not the best for smart and ambitious talents

headline: Great experience working at Qualcomm for several years.
pros: Management is highly technical and competent. Workforce is highly talented. Talent is suitably rewarded. Management has an open door policy and is receptive to feedback. New ideas are encouraged and there are lot of avenues to convert new ideas to projects.
cons:
Pace of work can be demanding at times, depending upon the group that you work for. 
Software Process has evolved chaotically over time and that leads to a lot of inefficiencies.

headline: Challenging experience..
pros: Good compensation and open door policy.. less bureaucratic...
cons: Need better worklife balance... stressful at times and very demanding.  Could be more realistic in deadlines and tragets.

headline: Was fun working at qualcomm
pros: Exciting work and and will get to work on new things in industry
cons: work life balance an neutral salary.

headline: The best company I have ever worked at.  This will be the company I plan to retire with.
pros: Amazing benefits and wonderful co-workers, to include leadership
cons: I don't like that they are a firm supporter of hiring military but then don't recognize Veteran's Day as a holiday.  I am a veteran.

headline: A stable and cutting edge technology giant
pros:
1. Company cares for its employees.
2. Stable job.
3. Great perks and bonuses.
4. Smart co- workers.
5. Opportunity to learn a lot and work with the best resources.
6. Promotions are fair.
7. Nice location esp if you are in San Diego.
cons:
1. Sometimes work can be stressful esp before important releases or if there are customer issues. But this practice is consistent across the industry.

2. Some leads are sitting on retirement territory and are hopeless and make you hopeless.

3. Other than this I can't think of any.

headline: not pleasant and a lot of pressure
pros: none everything was unpleasant and over worked
cons: too many bosses over worked and too many favoritisms

headline: Great place to work as long as you are in the right division
pros: Great pay and benifits can have growth opportunities if you are willing to give all to the company.
cons: Long Hours. Culture has shifted from chaging the world to meeting the next quarters numbers.

headline: Cutting edge communications company
pros: Perfect place to work for if you have communications technology background
cons: Silicon valley compensation package can be more competitive

headline: Its cool
pros: Great campus, environment, gym, life
cons: Too corporate, little collaboration, little room to grow

headline: Your mileage may vary depending on the management chain above you
pros:
At the working cross - functional level, the teamwork is phenomenal.  In fact, I would say that is the key to Qualcomm's success has been the quality of the teams executing.  There is a lot of mutual respect and get the job done can do attitude.   A lot of smart people that work incredible hours to achieve success.  I have nothing but good things to say about the people i worked with on a day-by-day basis. 

Good compensation and benefits.
cons: In some departments, the management chain is dysfunctional.  In my particular experience, some of us at the working level were excluded and isolated from information from above but at the same time, being held accountable to act with that information.  VP and SVP levels clearly lack leadership skills or the ability to leverage the people under them in an effective, unified team.   Again, this is not universal across Qualcomm.  It all depends on which department you end up.

headline: Great Employer!
pros: Qualcomm is filled with very innovative and really smart people. It's always very inspiring to see all the energy and shared vision of the mobile future. Heart to beat the combination of exciting work, great benefits and beautiful San Diego just about anywhere on the planet!
cons: Cannot really think of any! ...I'm just a die-hard fan of Qualcomm!

headline: One of the best companies to work for & build your career
pros:
-- Best in class benefits compared to industry peers
-- Lot of freedom to do your job, participate in cross functional projects & opportunity to learn cutting edge technology
cons: -- Nothing I can think of. Company is getting big, so you may not have same opportunities to get to work on important projects as 10 years back. You have to have some patience & earn that opportunity

headline: Awesome place to work at!
pros:
Excellent work to be done and good salary and benefits.
Hikes every 6 months
Have a chance to learn a lot if you are in development team
Great people around from whom you  can learn a lot.
cons:
Sometimes work pressures would be high.
You would be having knowledge only on your module. Maynot get a chance to learn about other technologies.
work load is not uniform. Sometimes it would be high and sometimes it would be less.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: High stress, but high reward environment.  Always new, interesing projects to work on.  Compensated very well.  I was promoted in a short amount of time and my Director has big plans for me downt he road.
cons: Hard to strike a good work/life balance if you want to keep advancing.  If you slow down to only 40-45 hrs a week, you are falling behind.  Twice a year review process is a waste of everyone's time.  Filling out 10-15 3rd party appraisals plus my own self review twice a year makes no sense.

headline: Great company, lot of upside
pros: very good engineers who have been working here for very long time
cons: quite big and usual slow growth

headline: The best place I have ever worked
pros: They have excellent benefits.  They treat the employees very well.  The facilities are excellent.  They seem to always make the right choices.
cons: I only worked in one group at the company, but from what I hear the work / life balance can vary by group.

headline: Great culture and people.  Service oriented and consensus driven.  Market Leader.  Excellent Benefits.
pros: Industry leader, innovative, strong culture where you have a voice and mgmt / peers will listen.  Flexible work environment and lots of ways to get involved.
cons: Depending on the group you work in, there can be a tendency of working long hours with high pressure, etc.  That is a function of the the semiconductor industry.  Environment can be ambiguous as well.

headline: Worked at the Q for 10 years. Wow hold on to your socks!
pros: Lots of fun and complicated stuff to work on with lots of challenges and as much work as you are willing to take on.  You will learn new tasks and lots of training.
cons: No work and life balance. They will work you 7 days a week if you let them.  In fact ehy have a saying.  If you don't come in on Sat then don't come back on Sun.

headline: Good
pros: Good benefits, Nice work culture
cons: More bureaucratic, Sometimes becomes monotonic

headline: Excellent place to work at! Excellent growth. Excellent Exposure
pros:
There are a lot of Pro's of working in Qualcomm India Pvt Ltd.
1. Best compensation and benefits 
2. Excellent work to be done. It depends actually which team you are a part of.
3. Good chance to work on latest and cutting edge technology
4. You would learn to response under pressure
5. Flexi work hours
6. Everyone gets their own laptop and work from home facility
7. You can even work with your own personal laptop. 
8. All communication happens over emails, so no one can steal anyone's credit.
9. RSU options available. 
10. ESPP's also available. 
11. Hikes happen 2 times in a year which is good.
12. Most folks in US are very easy to approach and talk to. 
13. Free breakfast and Lunch. 
14. Transportation subsidy. 
15. Mobile phones/ iPhone Subsidy.
16. Gym present on campus
cons:
Most of the Cons are as follows --> 
1. If not in the right team, you can end up being in support work in Qualcomm India Pvt Ltd. 
2. Work pressures in Qualcomm India are High.
3. Not all people are easily approachable in QIPL. 
4. US teams don't bother too much about hierarchy, but Qualcomm India still has that. 
5. Can't interact with most employees over talk because of language barrier. Most of them start/discuss in regional language and not in English
6. Learning curve is not too steep. If you are in development team, you would learn only your module. You may not have a chance to learn other Modules/Technology.

headline: Great company overall, good benefits, safe bet for now
pros:
Compensation package is good overall.
Benefits are great especially for higher titles. 
Secure company for now, great market position.
cons:
Benefits have some oddities... E.g. negotiated benefits would pay for adoption fees, but nothing for IVF or other infertility treatments which are typically covered to some extent in similar size companies.
Work/life balance can easily suffer in San diego with very aggressive schedules, over the last a few years schedules have become increasingly unreasonable.
Hiring in SD is too lax imho... There is some good talent but a lot of incompetence in some groups. The case is much better in regional offices where every req is scarce and scrutinized.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Innovative company, great benefits, great technology
cons: Nothing to comment on this

headline: Not everyone can be an Engineer
pros: Pay, benefits, location, on-site gym and other recreational options.
cons: They promote EVERYONE to his/her position of maximum incompetence. Oh, and if you don't have a degree in Engineering, don't expect to be hired here even for a job as a janitor.

headline: Money making at any cost
pros: salary, benefits, competitive environment, established company
cons: unrealistic expectations(`compromise everything to make profit`), very inconsistent decision making by the management, inefficient hr, authority is concentrated on very few individuals locally, less transparency, unnecessary competition between branches within, lack of trust between teams internally

headline: Excellent

headline: Very good place to work.

cons: Parking lot was once a pain, but now I would say progress when working with some other team may not be that efficient as desired. I guess this is a common issue among large IT companies.

headline: Good Stable Job
pros: Great people, benefits and values. If you want to settle down and raise a family it is a great option.
cons: too many meetings, freedom constrained by requirement to protect intellectual property, large bureaucracy, large company. In spite of the rhetoric about innovation, the individual isn't going to make a huge difference or change the world.

headline: awesome
pros: excellent team, technically brilliant set of folks to work with
cons: processes could be more stream lined

headline: Like a start-up, but without the cash flow issues.
pros: Lots of cutting edge wireless/embedded software work, across both 3G and 4G technologies.  Highly competent engineering workforce, fairly grueling interview process.  Good pay and benefits, no issues with career advancement if you're capable and willing to put in the effort.
cons: Not a sweatshop, but can be very demanding at times.  You must assert your own work/life balance, or the work and culture behind it will demand more and more from you.

headline: became a real engineer at Qualcomm
pros: was given plenty of latitude to try new things, but had plenty of mentoring to help build my real-world engineering skills
cons: a big company that sometimes I felt like a cog in the wheel

headline: A great place to work
pros:
The people are chosen very carefully, and are very smart and nice to work with. 
When you work in Qualcomm you have the option to move from one team to another easily. 
The work is very interesting.
cons: I believe the option to progress and proceed to management is hard because it takes some more time that other companies.

headline: Senior Audio Driver Engineer
pros: Great work culture, flexible working hours, change to work on cutting edge technology
cons: I cant really think of anything

headline: Your experience will depend on your group, but their culture of dishonesty let me down.
pros: Interesting engineering work but understaffed.
cons: After 5 years at Qualcomm my experience was mixed. It depends very much on the specifics of your group and management. If you join as an expert in your field you may find yourself working with inexperienced generalists who do not know what they are doing and rely on your expertise but who are then able to take all the glory. This is compounded by racial cliques in some small teams. From my management I got very mixed messages, heaping praise on the one hand then stabbing me in the back when it counted. It sounds nutty but In the end I encountered a pervasive culture of dishonesty from my managers up to and including senior HR that soured me to this company.

headline: Exposure to best of mobile technologies but lot of politics to deal with and no work life balance.
pros: They are leader in this field so you are definitely working for the best.
cons: Politics is way too much. Lot of credit stealing.

headline: overall it is good
pros: they provide good environment, salary and bonus. The city is very nice and beautiful. good work life balance, and you have enough time to enjoy you life.
cons: not good communication with manager. When you need help, it is not easy to find out whom you can ask help for.

headline: Still unpolished to be regarded as a industry-leading company

headline: Good money, no life

headline: One of the best in the semiconductor industry !
pros: Great people and awesome benefits. Salary is good and schedules are pretty flexible as long as you get the work done !

headline: Exciting fast-paced environment. Building the future with wireless technology.
pros: Never boring...Qualcomm is a place you can make your own career success by embracing the culture of constant change and not holding on to old processes.Great benefits, great facilities, best place to work in San Diego.
cons: It never slows down...Always more work than people to do it. incredible pressure to meet unrealistic goals & schedules at times. While that challenge can make a job exciting, it can also take a toll on you when it never lets up. Long hours have become the norm.

headline: Very demanding and competitive environment
pros: Continuous learning is a part of the environment, Work with great minds, Opportunity to execute.
cons: Working for 16 hrs a day is bad on your health. Totally depends on your team. Because of superfast execution, quality of work is poor.

headline: Lead Enigneer Sr

cons: No Work life balance.Managers do not respect this at all.In certain groups Work life balance is undefined word.Meeting scheduled on Saturday 11.PM is considered OK???

headline: Awesome place to work.

headline: Work very hard

Leadership in mobile modem and processor market
Best high tech place to work in San Diego

headline: Very good work environment for emolyee
pros: conducive and competitive work environment

headline: Great company
pros: Interesting projects, decent job growth. Nice people
cons: No cons as such; Bridgewater is a very slow and boring place to be.

headline: Great benefits, good people but shrinking prospects
pros: Benefits are the best in San Diego specially the health benefits. Other benefits like stocks, cash bonuses, ESPP, 401k, life insurance, vendor discounts and many more make this company a  competitive employer. Engineering culture is good but can be stressful due to deadlines.
cons: Can be political. Watch out for HR guys, they are not there to help you, there job is to look out for the company only. Negotiate well with them. Future prospects for the growth are questionable so the company tightening the belt.

headline: Great team and campus
pros: Great perks such as discounts to events, movies, amusement parks. Big campus with constant events for their employees. Friendly and intelligent group of coworkers. Lots of opportunities to advance your skill set.
cons: Lots of politics that come with a large corporate company unfortunately, but besides that I really enjoyed my experience here.

headline: Good company ruined by politics and dishonesty
pros: good money, flexibility in working hours
cons:
1.) There is higher than usual amount of what I would term vicious politics (its like a war in a zoo honestly); my direct superior distorted information constantly before giving info on project progress to middle management thereby making the real person doing the work look bad to make them look good - they will constantly throw you under the bus.  
2.) Lack of transparency and dishonesty; lots of closed door meetings where you are excluded because its more politics than work. 
3.) Backstabbing & gossip - lots of it. 
4.) Your direct report may not want to share knowledge necessary to do the work because they fear you will take over their own jobs, for the same reason they will not document work. 
5.) Culture clash - if you must work here you must be well versed in Chinese/ Indian values/ culture, for example, if you say what you honestly think and are completely honest, it may be considered a 'loss of face' and you will be punished. You dare not argue a valid point with superiors too. 
6.) Bad staff are let to stay because they are friends of management. 
7.) Limited chances for career advancement.

headline: A good company to work for
pros: Qualcomm provides competitive compensation. Lots of opportunities for internal training and learning. There are opportunities to do internal transfer to switch to a different area.
cons: Even though there are opportunities for training and learning, usually it's too busy to find time to take those lessons. Similar to most big company, you only get to work on a small scope of things.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Qualcomm - QCT - is full of surprises. It is a great place to work, and there are many things that are good for the employee: great employee relations, HR helps ensure manager apply consistent rules, and the benefits are good. You get a review every 6 months and get formal feedback each time.
cons: Here are the surprises: the management mindset is very much to reward the fire fighters, not the good managers who prevent the fires in the first place. There is great focus on execution and the delivery of quality product. However there is less attention to addressing inefficiencies. QCT runs many projects in parallel and does a good job as this. If I compare lower profile less interesting but high volume projects with the high profile, more interesting lower volume projects - the latter always get into trouble (because they are complex) and so get all the attention, and these team members seem to be better rewarded than the low profile teams who do a good job (and so don't need management attention).

headline: Mature process, immature IT management - no integrity
pros:
Qualcomm has a great work-life balance if your manager permits you to take advantage of it.
The medical benifits provided are great!
cons:
No integrity in IT Management
No recognition for new employees
Tasks/Projects/Milestones accomplished are not communicated up the management chain, especially in IT. Instead, the manager will take credit for great work and accomplishments and has at least one level below to blame when things don't go as favorably.
Very secretive and cowardly promotion and bonus/perk structures.
Will actively deny or make extremely difficult the ability to transfer internally.

headline: Qualcomm
pros: fairly good pay, good faculty, nice location. Your first impression on your management determine your future in this company. Don't stupid thing, then you can stay as long as you want.
cons: few chance to grow, not good working atmosphere, if you are good at presenting instead of hard working, you might fit this company.

headline: Great company to work for in san diego
pros: smart people, fast moving, lots of projects to work on, good pay & benefits
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Satisfying
pros: flexible, work -life balance, easy to manage
cons: too many people, can't think of anything

headline: Company facing execution challenges post QCOM acquisition
pros: Good benefits, smart talent across most engineering teams.
cons: Cross functional teams not aligned resulting in product slips. No corporate-wide system in place for career growth, too many layers, poor team environment and low employee morale.

headline: Not the worst place to work at
pros:
Stuff you work on will generally be interesting 
Coworkers are  pretty good
Solid process for programmers (versioning systems, code review etc) 
Large enough teams so work is evenly distributed 
Good opportunity to be exposed to new things 

Best pro is that I'm usually into my work enough that time passes by quickly and I'm generally excited for Mondays.
cons:
No commitment to flow of knowledge. You can often be assigned to a unfamiliar project with very little idea of what you're supposed to do. (the project lead will have the high level overview but good luck getting him to explain it to you). More often than not it's baptism by fire. To be fair they're getting better about documentation now
Code quality varies across teams, drastically. A lot of legacy code needs be maintained. 
Work load very unpredictable. There are weeks when you have nothing to do, and weeks where 24 hours isn't enough in a day. 
Some of the higher level managers have overly aggressive in deadlines and no one bothers reigning them in
Too much administrative crud (I assume it's everywhere). 
Pay comparatively sucks.

headline: New software engineer
pros: Great people who are very smart.
cons: As with any large corporation that is comprised of mostly software engineers, it's pretty easy to get stuck doing the same thing for a long time.

headline: Challenging and fast paced
pros: Fast paced, technology focused, leaders in Mobile technology
cons: Customer driver goals make it difficult on employees with frequent changes in task objectives

headline: A sweatshop in the USA. Long hours are inevitable. If you have a life at all, let it go before you work here.
pros: Some discounts around town for employees.
cons:
# No work- life balance.

# Most work almost 12 hours everyday. Not the managers maybe, but for a new recruit, that is a minimum for months.

# Salary is very less for the extremely demanding work.

# Terrible work culture.

# Half the work force is Temp employees. That says a lot about how Qualcomm wants to save more and pay the absolute least it can.

headline: great company and great people
pros: superior technology, great people, great management,

headline: RF support engineer

headline: A good company to work for, but you need to work really hard

Good compensation on par with Industry standard
Half-yearly performance review and merit hikes
Considerable Bonus and Stock Award payments
cons:
Throughout they year, there is a heavy-work-load
High pressure on delivery.  You will never be cut out of work any point of time, including weekends

headline: Wonderful
pros: Learning experience is wonderful at QC.
cons: Work can get a bit hectic

headline: Qualcomm is a great place to be.
pros: Pay, Opportunity, Wide scope, upcoming company, aggressive
cons: Work load , hectic , tight schedule

headline: Amazing experience, helpful colleagues..Really good work atmosphere, Best place to work !
pros: you get to learn a lot of things from a team of professionals
cons: I was an intern here.. So can't comment on this..Sorry !

headline: Downward spiral
pros: The pay is excellent and you really are working with the cream of the crop, best of the best, etc. The engineers and designers there are amazing.
cons: The company is cutting the employees' benefits and perks a little every year. When I started a decade ago, everyone got an office, our pay was in the top %ile, insurance was top notch, there were device and education subsidies. Over time, each of these is vanishing; our salaries are median at best, our insurance is okay but not great, our device subsidies have vanished. And the list goes on. It's still an ok company to work for, but it is coasting on a previous reputation, and isn't nearly as great as it once was.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Various of interesting software chalenging projects
cons: It is still difficult to receive an ownership over some interesting staff

headline: Good entry level job in Qualcomm
pros: Good salary, working environment, training platform
cons: Too concentrate on your special field, few chance to get close to other work

headline: Aggressive company, good compensation
pros: Aggressively pushes forward on mobile across all areas, on cutting edge of mobile technology expansion. Lots of opportunity for top engineers to contribute and grow into technical leadership roles. Relative to other companies I have worked at, pretty non-political organization. Strong and fair compensation (based on company performance) across all tiers of engineering. Engineering centric org. Generally engineers are hard working, smart, and decent people.
cons: Pace of product development and delivery can be rough on engineering. Being remote to San Diego is still a bit of an issue, although vastly less than 5 years ago. Not that good of a place for mediocre/run-of-the-mill engineers. Could use some improving on campus perks relative to other Bay Area options.

headline: Awesome place to work with great values
pros: Great co workers and management,
cons: Work life gets hectic at times

headline: Qcom India is a mixed bag depending on one's view . Read through
pros:
1.) Currently the best semiconductor company making huge chunk of money. 
2.) Gets exposure to the latest techniques and the complex designs. I would say best for an experienced physical design engineer.
3.) Free Transport/B'fast/Lunch/Snacks. Reach office by 8 and leave by 5, but connect from home and work rest :-)
4.) From staff engineer and above, you just need to get hm's delivered  and would be called either hm/super hm lead without doing any work.
5.)Good salary + stocks + half yearly apprasial & bonus.

If one can just ignore on the cons, mind your work and doesnt need to have a social life at home/office would be a good place to work.
Atlast all of us work for money.
cons:
1.) Exponential growth in terms of hiring, which needs to seen with a caution. Not sure for how long smartphone revolution continues and such inorganic growth will sustain without layoffs.
2.) Not a good company to start career as one would get expert in running scripts and filing jira tickets rather than understanding the issue and fixing it yourself using your own brain.. Best would be to join QCOM after 5 years of exposure at small companies where there isnt a flow to support you.
3.) Inefficient / technically unfit  managers spoil the culture, who is only concerned about deliverable's like a serrvices company  and not keen on making an engineer learn/understand and fix. Most senior managers who came through acquisition
4.) Most engineers work more than 15 hours a day. 

5.) Lot of regional bias attitude and most doesnt speak English most of the time even in meetings.
6.) BDC doesnt have the quality and standard of an US MNC in facilities / team outings/project parties when compared o QCOM Hyderabad office.

7.) No personal time even on weekends.

8.) QCOM blore (BDC)

headline: A political quagmire orchestrated by managers too busy proving how smart they are
pros: Good benefits, very talented engineers, not too bureaucratic for a company of its size
cons:
At least 50% of the managers are totally incompetent as managers. They are busy playing politics all day long and trying to force their agenda on others. Most managers act like individual contributors whose directs exist for the sole purpose of cleaning their leftovers. 
Agreeing on expectations, providing feedback, asking instead of commanding and coaching is something I haven't seen from any manager in this company. This is all a result of a poor management culture and promotion for the wrong reasons. The organizational hierarchy is so vertical that most managers have fewer than 4 directs. This means you need to to fill an awful lot of management positions from a pool for technocrats, how well can this turn out to be? Senior management is completely detached. To illustrate it, 16,000 company employees (60%) report to a single manager who sits 3 levels below the CEO.

- poor coding practices in certain teams, bad function names and mispellings get propagated because nobody ever steps up to fix them.
- 3 years average promotion time for engineers, which seem to be longer than alot of other companies, this adds to the lack of accomplishment
- line management, your line manager has no clue what you did in the past quarter nor do they care.  They evaluate you based on an online form filled out by your colleagues and given the impersonal nature of the evaluation (no personal interaction), people get bored of bubbling things in and writing canned answers they just dont try to write anything amazing about you.
- they give you lots of bonuses and stock options to keep you here, but rarely actually bump your salary

headline: Good for Developers/Engineers, not for IT Staff
pros:
Qualcomm has world class software developers and hardware engineers that make amazing products. The company culture is to give these engineers whatever tools they need to get the job done in the right way. Some may call them "spoiled", but this boosts their productivity. Healthcare is nearly free (minimal co-pays, no cost premium, good coverage for other services), company culture is great, working on a lot of leading edge technologies. 

A lot of "Q" this and "Q" that (e.g. QLife, etc.) and they order in lunch often, have free sodas and snacks, and a lot of people get real offices vice being in a cube farm. Certainly not a Google where you get completely free meals and you can bring your pet to work, but a good innovative culture. Twice a year bonuses, cash awards, and stock grants are great. Qualcomm really puts a lot of time and effort into the twice-yearly review process. They really do a 360 degree view of the person with third party input. Most thorough review process I've ever seen.
cons:
Working in IT at Qualcomm is filled with cons and few positives. IT staff are second class citizens, playing second fiddle to developers and "real" engineers. Yes they bring in the money, but a professional IT degreed engineer is not compensated or looked at in the same way as a developer. Since the "real" engineers are fairly spoiled, IT is constantly being pulled at their whim with little planning or time to do it right. Highly reactive, which often results in less than optimal IT solutions. Engineers then look down upon IT for providing half-baked solutions, even when we were totally left out of any up-front planning and they need something "yesterday". 

Corporate IT is also highly siloed, and people get put in a box and rarely let out. If you are an Exchange administrator, then you have zero insight into storage, virtualization, networking, etc. Or maybe all you do is administer load balancers. Very little cross-discipline training or exposure. This stunts IT skills and IT careers. Everyone has their rice bowls, and getting major tasks accomplished that cross multiple groups is very painful. The helpdesk tries their best, but lacks good training and skilled staff. Extremely high turnover, and not very happy customers. 

Because the perks and company are good overall, the poor IT performers stay and rarely seem to leave. Getting HR to fire someone is nearly impossible and takes 6-9 months if not more, even if the person clearly is not even remotely performing at their level. HR is highly risk adverse, which causes major pain for staff managers and makes the teams suffer. 

Bottom line is if you want to work in IT, don't go to Qualcomm. If you are a skilled software developer or hardware engineer, Qualcomm may be your perfect job.

headline: Stable company but bad work life balance and pretentious
pros: Qualcomm is a very stable company, so there's no fear if the company will survive. The insurance policy is great for employees with family. Corporate identity is strong and there are quarterly team building events. Performance reviews are twice  a year, but might not be getting more increment than companies with yearly reviews.
cons: Work life balance is bad, and I have feedback about this to my supervisor, only to be told that "that's the way it is". The twice-yearly performance review system is a farce, the increments are more like yearly increment being spread out twice, and the increments are never worth the hours that we put in. Increment amounts are also dubious, and can differ > 5% between employees with same work function. The general focus is not on the engineering work, but on creating "visibility" for yourself, which seems to be the top "unwritten" agenda; if you've done good work and you don't sell/promote to your supervisors, its your own fault because its not their job to know and recognize what you've done. Some managers seems to be more concerned about VIP visits and RC activities than the real engineering work. Way too many meetings.

headline: High Quality Employees
pros: Employees are very bright, first-rate, and have can-do attitudes.  The culture of the company is excellent - employees at all levels are encouraged to exercise judgment, make decisions, provide opinions, share information across departments, and also to continue to develop their own skills in many areas.  Primary employee benefits such as medical, dental, vision coverage, and compensation are first-rate, plus there are the additional benefits of  stock options, bonuses, and many other extras.  In general, this is a company that understands that their employees are their greatest asset.  Many of the folks in management have good management skills.  As hard as people work at Qualcomm, most people really like working there because of the dynamic and challenging environment and the sense of accomplishment and teamwork.   There are very good training opportunities within the company.  It would be difficult for anyone to not learn a great deal of useful knowledge and skills while working there.
cons: Employees work long hours, typical of most high tech companies.  Evenings, weekends, and holidays are not sacred either.  At any level of the company you can be expected to be called when you are needed.  This is not exactly a con but more the reality of being at a successful high tech company.  It is, however, very busy and very stressful, and if you don't thrive in that kind of atmosphere then it is not the place for you.  There is increasingly a more political atmosphere, which is really a shame.  It was probably inevitable with the growth of the company over time, but it has greatly lessened the enjoyment of the workplace overall and added to the stress level.  I feel that as the company has gotten so much larger, there is not enough understanding at the executive levels of the day-to-day trials at the working level and middle management level.  This has also added to the frustration of people who put so much of themselves into their work.
